Throughly addicted.   Not just driving, but a true test of skill threading the needle... where instead of cotton, you're threading a 25 tonne pantechnicon through a set of bollards only a few feet wider than yourself.... At 50mph... on a time limit...   Truly fun.   

When I first started playing this, I was using a keyboard and mouse, and didn't really care about what I was doing.  I was careening into cars, smashing into crash barriers and tipping cargo all over the M1.  Then I started to grok what the game was really about,  being a perfectionist...  

Optimising the money you earn per hour of your time is what this is about.  As the best driver  you can easily earn ten to twenty times the amount of any other driver... But then, what if you hire ten or twenty other drivers?  You can take the time to do more relaxing jobs, buy a nice truck, buy a nice livery and post pictures on Twitter of your sweet ride.   But you can only do that with scads of cash, and you need skills and a workforce to do it.

Once you get eight or more drivers, you start to see the cash build.  They collectively earn about the same as you, and you just have to keep pushing the tin around the map until you get garages all over the continent.

Once that's done, you're free and clear to start enjoying yourself.

The Simulator you expect to never like but somehow fall in love with, Euro Truck Simulator 2 lets you experience the world of cargo haulage right at your PC and it does it very well for the most part. You start with nothing, just taking low paying jobs in the quick job menu but gradually you will expand your company until you have your very own fleet of trucks and truckers all across Europe.

+Great graphics, the trucks and trailers in particular are very high quality
+Large map made even larger by the Going East DLC and the Scandinavia expansion
+The system of building up your company works well and as you improve as a driver it becomes easier to improve your company
+It's a very relaxing game and is a perfect excuse to listen to music, podcasts or the radio
+You can play your music or a radio station through the game's menu
+Trucks have lots of customisation options
+Lots of different skills to improve to make yourself a better driver or to unlock new types of cargo
+The paint job packs are very high quality and in my opinion are worth their price (especially on sale)
+Plenty of great mods and it's very easy to install mods
+Controls are fully customisable
+Plenty of different cargo types, especially with the High Power pack and some of the skills you can unlock
+Several truck manufacturers with several truck designs each
+Seat heights, lights used etc are all customisable
+Has a photo mode with lots of different options allowing you to take plenty of nice shots of your truck
+The devs run events which give you the opportunity to unlock exclusive content through the World of Trucks website
+It's easy to progress through the game without taking loans from the bank which is good for players who want to maximise their rewards in-game

+/-Pretty hard to play with a mouse and keyboard but this is more than made up for with the controller and wheel support, if you don't have a controller or a wheel you might find this significantly more challenging to play

-The AI can be pretty poor sometimes, AI vehicles almost always travel faster than the speed limit, trucks in particular have acceleration faster than makes sense, cars will sometimes accelerate into you while you are turning rather than stop
-Major cities do not resemble cities in anyway, they are very small and all cities have a similar layout (a repair shop, two distributors, somewhere to sleep and a garage)
-Major cities do not have gas/petrol stations so you have to rely on service stations on major highways for fuel
-Doesn't have different seasons which seems odd considering they run seasonal events, such as the Winter Holiday event (seeing as you had to deliver presents it would seem logical to have snow)

driving to paris in the darkness hours, speeding down the highway at a gingerly 120/km, blasting cbat in the background i can hardly pay attention to the road infront of me. suddenly i see on my minimap that there is a roundabout up ahead, not realising the mistake i have just made. i prepare myself in this event but mistakingly pressing the right key instead of left. i can see a sedan infront of me with a family of 4, my heart drowns in sorrow as i smash my 4.4 tonne truck into them, instantly killing all of them instantly, without a second word. i gaze into my monitor of what horrors i have committed...
i immediately respawn at the nearest city and continue my journey from there.

Many games attempt this genre and fail.
Euro Truck Simulator 2 succeeds in capturing that one essential thing which makes or breaks a good delivery sim: a living breathing world.

Although technically not fully open world, ETS 2 manages to deliver the best-in-genre type of open world to drive in. Combine that with an enjoyable delivery management system, great driving mechanics and an awesome coop experience. 

It is simply the best and most addicting fun I've had yet for a game of this kind!

This is the best truck simulator ever. It has 100s of settings that you can change to match your style of playing. Graphics, you can assign a steering wheel, you can turn on or off automatic ignition, automatic turning off indicators. Yeah. There are countless settings. Turns out driving a truck through the night under light rain, while listening to local radio stations, was my dream job. Gamepad or controller is good in this game, but if you have racing wheel it will be 10 / 10 experience.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Like its American counterpart which I have played more as of the time of writing, the original Euro Truck Simulator 2 also encompasses the feeling of trucking in the dense and interesting roads of both European countries as well as the UK.

I can wholly say that this is a great simulation of the feeling of European Trucking along the differing roads and weather conditions of European countries, whether be it on the left or right side of the road, day or night, rain or shine. There's that sense of serenity that comes with cruising on the highway as well as the annoyance when stuck in traffic, I suppose.

For a game released initially in 2012, I am glad it is still in active development, garnering overwhelmingly positive reviews all throughout. Instead of another game released yearly and under a mandatory paywall for others to enjoy, this one is different. Not to mention, when sales come by, you can pick up the map DLCs for fairly cheap.

Graphics-wise, the game has gotten pretty good as of 1.45, but of course should you not be satisfied nevertheless, there always are mods to counter that issue ‚Äî or any issue you may find with the game, even.

The modding scene with this game is among the largest I've ever come across, spanning different versions of the game as well as changing from the littlest of detail to even improving or adding to the whole map itself.

Definitely a game that I'd recommend you to try, whether you're a casual person who likes freeroam driving games or is a person that is an avid or real life trucker. Frankly quality and solid. 10/10, would completely recommend. If you have a friend who likes driving or peaceful games, then this one I recommend as a gift.


TL;DR: Much like its American counterpart, it's an equally solid game due to great gameplay, good graphics, excellent modding community, and also fits any type of person ‚Äî from casual freeroam driver or real life trucker. Trucking and cruising on the highways and roads have a serene and peaceful experience to it, which makes the general experience 3x better.

May be I am a bit spoiled by SnowRunner but I find there is very little point to continue playing this game. May be things are different once you buy some of the newer DLCs, but in the 8 hours I have spent with the "Essential Bundle" I have seen:

- very little variety in mission types
- very little variety in the paths used, mostly highway to highway
- very little challenge
- large parts of cities are inaccessible 
- great cities like London and Paris have been very underwhelming in the facilities, activities and experience they provide.
- an UI that is ugly, tedious, and dated (but there is a flat UI mod that makes it a bit prettier).
- most disappointingly of all, the trucks have very little variety. There are only a handful of trucks compared to similar games, and the driving experience is nearly identical from one truck to another. The upgrades I have tried have also made very little difference in the experience. IMHO the various DLC regions should have come with their local Truck manufacturers (or fictional ones inspired by them). And there should be other types of trucks of multiple shapes and sizes.

There are some positives:
+ The management side of things is a bit of standout among similar games. You can buy and upgrade garages. Hire NPC drivers to handle your extra trucks. This side of the game should be further expanded with management of your company and garage staff, 
+ Their DLC model of expanding the map gradually by adding more areas is ideal for a game like this. Other sim devs (:cough: Dovetail Games :cough:) should learn from this. I imagine that with all DLCs this is probably larges open world for on-road travelling, even with the game's scaled down geography, with several real world hours of travelling required to reach one end from another. I imagine those lengthy relaxing virtual drives are why so many love this game. Unfortunately for me the core gameplay is not interesting enough and the DLCs not cheap enough to try it for myself.
+ There is an abundance of mods. 

Some people will likely think 8 hours is not long enough for me to evaluate this game. But the thing is why should I continue to play something I have not enjoyed? If the game takes more than 8 hours to get going, it is a problem with the game's design.

I have read the devs are revisiting old areas to overhaul them. Perhaps that will improve the areas of the map that I have tried so far. I will try it again next year and update this review, and possibly invest more time and money.

this game deserves its spot as the pioneer truck game and it delivers an almost proper truck driving experience with many decent aspects it offers. The driving feeling, maneuvers, and loads definitely make you realize how heavy and huge vehicles trucks are. Long routes for shipping goods may seem tedious at the beginning but they are worth it when you deliver them and make money from them. There are diverse roads and sceneries which look fantastic. 

The biggest handicap for some may be the fact that you may get bored after a while if you play with keyboards. Starting your own business is a good way to hold on to the game if you feel bored due to driving. Of course playing with steering wheel is the best way to experience this game. it takes the game into another league by offering super enjoyable and realistic gameplay.

As a result of my evaluation, I can sincerely say that it is an excellent game overall. Anyone who is into cars or just a relaxing game should definitely try it.

AITA for accidentally running over a family of 4

This happened early this morning. I, (68 M) and my wife (18 F) were celebrating our ten year anniversary and we wanted to go to a special fancy restaurant to celebrate. Me and my wife got into my 2004 truck named Bessy and I started up the car to drive up to Wendy's. I was following the Google maps suggestion and was looking at the map, when suddenly i noticed I was approaching a crosswalk. This was no big deal on its own, but suddenly my virgin eyes had been violated by the intense glare of the suns rays bouncing off the heads of four seperate bald people crossing the road. After being flashed violently by these hazardous bald heads I immediately cried out my war cry mating call while my wife was begging me to stop. I let out a stomp to assert my dominance against my wife (Who was going through a puberty mood swing), forgetting that I was the driver. My intense and very powerful stomp had landed on the gas pedal, and my good old truck Bessy had started speeding towards the Bald family like a pissed off bull. Before I could react, we had already rammed into the four baldies at 80 miles per hour. The family of four (Now one because three of them had died from my intense stomp stomp) had taken me to court for quote unquote "manslaughter" but I see this as "innocently trying my best to drive even in the midst of a traffic violation". I don't think I am the asshole, and my wife agrees with me that it's their fault for being bald in the open like that, and flashing innocent drivers. AITA?

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is very simple but incredibly addictive. Driving through the European countryside is very soothing and makes the perfect backdrop for listening to music or a podcast. For those of us who need to keep their hands stimulated while they listen to something, this game is absolutely ideal. Your brain can go on autopilot while you go on long drives delivering cargo or simply exploring the map.

The developers continue to update it despite the fact that it's nearly ten years old. There are also regular DLC packs, but prices are fair and the only packs you really need are the ones that add large swaths of driving area to the map. You never feel pressured to buy anything.

The addition if driver/truck/garage management systems was a nice touch that takes it from simply being a driving simulator to something that has an additional axis of progress you can work towards beyond your player's driving skills. It feels good to be able to do my own deliveries and watch my trucking company expand at the same time.

Road trip simulator with unexpected bonusses

I bought this game somewhere in 2020. I was looking for a ideal timesink with high replayability, when this game popped up in my list... As I have no affiliation with trucks whatsoever (besides occassionaly admiring their chonk as they plod along the highways) i was somewhat apprehensive about buying a game about moving trucks from one place to another. But the game was on sale so what could go wrong?.

Two years later i have bought most of the map expansions for the game and logged 250 hours. So far this game has surpassed my initial expectations. The concept is very simple: you have a truck, hook up to a cargo and transport it to any old place in europe.

But the game is more than doing this repetitive action over and over again. What makes this game stand out to me is the way it manages to make you feel as if you  really are moving through different countries. The developers have put a surprising amount of effort into details such as traffic signs, road markings and roundabouts. This is especially true for the more recent map expansions.

Besides this, the game gives you the freedom to customize your experience as you see fit. Play with traffic fines or not, speed limiter on or off. You are als not forced into only transporting cargo. If you want to roam free and discover all  european road systems, you are free to do so.

And as an added bonus it seems to magically improve your trailer parking abilitys. I found myself in charge of a sizeable pickup with a little trailer as part of my work and despite having  no previous real live experience, i had no problem backing it up and parking it. So there  is that!

For me the mayor pros of this game are:
- The detailed road systems (at least in the new locations)

- The freedom and customization abillitys of the game

- The feel of driving is well simulated (especially with wheel and pedals)

- Very few bugs, i have encountered none so far.

- Active dev team. They regularly organise events, which can be completed and reward you with cosmetic items for your truck. They are still (this game was released in 2008!!!) pushing out updates to make the game better, so +1 for that.

The cons:
- The game does show its age in some of the older parts of the map such as england and scandinavia. The environment there isn't as detailed as in the newer parts.

- At some point all of the highway driving got a bit stale for me. There is a big focus on highways in the game, which is only natural of course as it is probably the trucks favoured habitat. But i personally really like discovering the more rural and built up areas and there is proportionally less of that in the game. But recent updates have improved this somewhat.

- Physics. There are no simulations for loss of grip, overheating brakes or jackkniving trailers. Crashing the truck or AI cars can also lead to an awkward dance party. But that is a minor point. 

Final note
I think the game is best played with a controller or wheel and pedals, as using a keyboard means you will be constantly pressing left  - right- left - right in order to go straight.

If you have but a slight interest in roadtrips or travelling through pretty landscapes, this game is a definite recommendation. Even if you have no interest in trucks at all!

Been playing this sim a lot. It's relaxing and beautiful especially if you have a sim racing setup with triple screens. The FOV setup is very important if you wish to achieve excellent sim experience and immersion. It is worth spending some time fiddling with different options like FFB, FOV and mapping buttons to suit your play style and visuals. Just like any other sim or game, more time spent gives you better results. As for the performance, even if you own the best GPU, some game locations will have heavy stuttering or low fps.

Many hours and a few DLCs into ETS2, I have no hesitation about recommending this game. Among simulators, this has one of the best base game mechanics‚Äîthe game offers exactly what you'd expect. The locations are interesting, and the DLCs have only gotten better at offering up novel locations to drive through. The developers are communicative and responsive. As a result, this game does not feel dated. I've gotten my money's worth and then some.

Still early hours, but after 11 hours of grinding I finally have my own truck and getting some pay days! The start really is a grind for buying your own truck, but the reward for getting that first truck and all the customisations you can play with from the start is a great feeling! It would be nice to start off with a truck, something like Truck Driver on PS4 (my first truck sim game) but the positive in ETS2 is that you get to test drive many of the trucks before purchase, so really you are saving a lot of money making sure your first truck is one you really get on with. So I don't really hold it negatively though the loan options didn't show for me, I could see very high offers for loans but couldn't select them. Its no big thing, I'm here for the trucks and it doesn't disappoint there, but I'm definitely happiest when customising my own wheels!
Its such an eye opener when comparing console gaming to PC! ETS2 is HUGE! The map (even DLC free), trucks on offer, trailers, and the massive customisation options available too. So far its run very smooth for me and I only run a basic 4+ year old ¬£500 prebuild PC. an AMD FX-8300 Eight-Core Processor 3.30 GHz. NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1050 Ti. 8GB RAM. And I can play on High and Ultra settings smoothly. I play my own music too, simply add MP3 music files to your documents/ETS2/Music folder. Loads of options for graphics, sound, GPS, map, layouts and truck controls, you can have a very simple auto setup for new players or go full on sim mode.
I've yet to try out the convoys! Something I am very interested in doing! So far this game has ticked all the boxes I was hoping from it. And I got it in the sales for something like ¬£6!!! This was like receiving a gift.. from myself! Loving the feel of the trucks and the scenery.

Just 3 minor things at the moment are negative,
1. I can't get the cruise control to work which is a pain as I play with controller so trigger throttle isn't easy to maintain a reliable speed. I've had so many tickets by going 1 or 2 mph over the limit.
2. There is an area in England (SE), sadly can't remember where precisely but its off a motorway onto a carriageway with a fuel and rest stop where being on the left lane penalises you for driving on the wrong side of the road.
3. The road coming out of Calais into England (on England's side) goes up a steep ramp to a fast motorway with a blind corner and no lights, so you literally have to guess if you can go or not. And with the uphill struggle you end up stuck in the path of traffic flying at you! Had loads of Channel Tunnel short runs and every time I would look for any sign of lights and either I need an eye check up or there just isn't anything there,
None are game breaking but would love to see those looked into, if I find the road with the penalty I'll try to come back to edit it here. But even with those 3 things I'm still giving this a solid 10/10. And that's before even experiencing the convoys..
Definitely a must for truck and sim lovers.

Travel across Europe as king of the road, a trucker who delivers important cargo across impressive distances! With dozens of cities to explore from the UK, Belgium, Germany, Italy, the Netherlands, Poland, and many more, your endurance, skill and speed will all be pushed to their limits. If you've got what it takes to be part of an elite trucking force, get behind the wheel and prove it!

Simulation games aren't for everyone, but there are still valid reasons for why Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a game that is worthwhile. With an overwhelmingly positive review score on Steam, and over five million copies sold on the platform, Euro Truck Simulator 2 makes the case as the best simulation game period.

You think its going to be boring right? Because driving around at 56mph down motorways isnt very exciting but its very fun. Its challenging, you learn new things and its actually really engaging and relaxing. Personally i would recommend buying the DLC too because it adds more locations and really enhances the game. Also would recommend downloading ProMods which transforms the game (google it). Only bad points for me are that the trucks in game are not the latest versions anymore (apart from the DAF) and the money that you earn for jobs seems to be very high (not realistic). On top of this once youve got a truck and built your business then some of the fun leaves the game because youve done everything. The only thing left to do at that point is drive around making more and more money that you dont really have anything to spend on because youve already got a business, trailers, trucks etc.

So as far as a review goes this game is top shelf, if you enjoy driving games of any kind you will like this game, for the most part bug free, most negative reviews are from folks that pile on mods that cause their troubles, SCS does excellent work and while the games graphics do show their age in places SCS are always upgrading both ETS2 and ATS so it's always getting even better.
Another great aspect are simply the game play options, there are a ton of them, SCS understands that not all players want the same experience and they give you the options to play the game your way.
As far as content the base game has enough to keep a casual player busy for hundreds of hours then add in the very reasonably priced DLC's and you can spend hundreds more.
If you are North American and play ATS and need some more tucking in your life don't be afraid to dive into ETS2 it's a real pleasure to jump between the two games and enjoy all that both have to offer.
As with any comments here on Steam this is only my humble opinion but ETS2 is a really great game made by a great developer, read some of the reviews and for sure check out some vids, I think you will buy it.

The truck simulation is excellent and the basic mechanics of driving across a beautifully simulated version of Europe are fun, but other parts of the simulation feel shockingly unpolished. Other vehicles' AI is buggy, the application of traffic fines sometimes makes no sense (e.g headlight violations in broad daylight), and random detours can add hundreds of km to your route without your GPS warning you or suggesting alternatives. Collision damage, fines, and detours can all be turned off in the extensive settings, but this undermines the realism that is the game's bread and butter. I'm amazed the non-truck parts of the game still feel so rough when it's been out for nearly 10 years.

Personally, I like to put on some music I haven't heard for a while, and go for a drive.  
That's all I want from this game :)

Euro Truck Simulator 2.
A game being in development since a decade. The main core of the game stays the same as it was back days, except developers still provides new content. Either by refreshing existing cities or developing new regions dlc's with reasonable price tags.
SCS Software are legit one of best developers nowadays.  They're Constant support to their hidden gem of sim games, as well as listening to fans feedbacks.

Graphically it did get old but still is pleasing to eyes. 
Gameplay wise. Its simply brilliant, so relaxing game, to do something meanwhile listening to music. 

If you're a sim fan, this is definitely a game for you. Always something to do, tons of achievements to get, and i dont mean here steam achievements (tho these exists too).
Being able to buy your first truck without taking a loan is an achievement on its own, and gives a nice feeling of accomplishing something. 

If you ever wanted to make your own company this is game for you. Simply AMAZING career mode.

I own nearly everything ETS2 and American Truck Simulator related as well.  Boring it is not. The difficulty scales well. Controller and wheel-pedal support are fine.  You can prefer short or long hauls.  It gets updates often.  The community is solid.  It is IMO a lot of fun.
its fun and has great graphics
good time killer when other games are downloading!

I'm 16 yo boomer, who likes sitting in front of my pc. Normally I have nothing to do, so I turn on steam and the first game I see is Euro Truck Simulator 2. I just run it and the time just  go by very quckly. 
You just go through many  missions and jobs, earn money, then you can buy your own truck. I recommend playing it on steering wheel with pedals, but you can also play on keyboard. It's really relaxing just sitting and driving some trucks. It gets better when you get more and more dlc like going east, italy, vive la france, scandinavia or even heavy cargo pack. You also gain steam cards which you can use to craft a badge that gives you xp. 
Overall, after 25 hours in the game, I didn't get tired of it even once. And the most important thing is that this game is not really expensive. I bought it on a -75% sale with some dlc. Hope you enjoyed the review, and have fun with ypur trucks!

STEP 1
To make the base, butter and line a 23cm loose-bottomed tin with baking parchment. Put the digestive biscuits in a plastic food bag and crush to crumbs using a rolling pin. Transfer the crumbs to a bowl, then pour over the melted butter. Mix thoroughly until the crumbs are completely coated. Tip them into the prepared tin and press firmly down into the base to create an even layer. Chill in the fridge for 1 hr to set firmly.

For more detail on how to make a biscuit base, take a look at our how to make a biscuit base video.

STEP 2
Slice the vanilla pod in half lengthways, leaving the tip intact, so that the two halves are still joined. Holding onto the tip of the pod, scrape out the seeds using the back of a kitchen knife.

STEP 3
Pour the double cream into a bowl and whisk with an electric mixer until it‚Äôs just starting to thicken to soft peaks. Place the soft cheese, icing sugar and the vanilla seeds in a separate bowl, then beat for 2 mins with an electric mixer until smooth and starting to thicken, it will get thin and then start to thicken again. Tip in the double cream and fold it into the soft cheese mix. You‚Äôre looking for it to be thickened enough to hold its shape when you tip a spoon of it upside down. If it‚Äôs not thick enough, continue to whisk. Spoon onto the biscuit base, starting from the edges and working inwards, making sure that there are no air bubbles. Smooth the top of the cheesecake down with the back of a dessert spoon or spatula. Leave to set in the fridge overnight.

STEP 4
Bring the cheesecake to room temperature about 30 mins before serving. To remove it from the tin, place the base on top of a can, then gradually pull the sides of the tin down. Slip the cake onto a serving plate, removing the lining paper and base. Pur√©e half the strawberries in a blender or food processor with the icing sugar and 1 tsp water, then sieve. Pile the remaining strawberries onto the cake, and pour the pur√©e over the top.

This is probably one of the best simulators I have ever played. Its realistic art style, feel of weight and interactive controls for your trucks (such as a Light Horns, Indicators and much more...) create extraordinary and addicting gameplay, minus the patience you have to have for traffic and long road trips of course.

Speaking of, I've decided to accumulate a list of pros and cons during my time.
Pros:
- Smart AI drivers outweigh the Dumb AI drivers
- AI response to player actions (Waiting for player to make turn or let them turn etc)
- Developer response to road designs (Example: The first road to enter the highway near Calais after exiting the Channel Tunnel)
- Details (Braking while its raining has a chance to make the player hydroplane, braking too hard stalls the engine, AI turns engine off when waiting to use fuel pump during long queues)

Cons:
- Most roads need immediate redesign as it is almost impossible to enter a motorway/highway on a junction
- Some roads and terrain show the "underworld"
- UK noticeably needs a rework as the motorways are way too "twisty" as opposed to the actual UK
- AI brake checks player randomly, especially when there is nothing wrong nor on a hard corner (a car passed just to get in-front of me in the UK and brake checked just to enter a petrol station)
- SATNAV rarely attempts to make player go through blocked areas
- Some areas with invisible walls have no blockers

Overall, as long as these small little cons don't get on your nerves, I believe this is one of the best simulators out there. 

Important Note: If you wanna expand and buy the DLC(s) sometime...I recommend waiting until they go on sale for 50% or 75%. ¬£3.99 for 6,000km+ of map expansion is an absolute steal.

Despite the name this isn't a simulator. Not in the full sense of the word. Your definition may vary but for me the goal of a simulation is to try to depict the reality as much as possible. I know that full simulation is not always desired as there still needs to be some gameplay value which may require certain shortcuts and simplifications. Still, this game doesn't even seem to strive to be an actual simulator. It clearly tries to attract a bigger community by following a more simcade-y path.

In a similar way as we talk about "walking simulators", we could also derive a term "driving simulator". And I believe this is what suits this game the most. It's impossible to fail, there's no place where your truck can't fit and you need to avoid, roads seems wider than in reality and every mistake can be easily forgiven due to simplified economy. The process of loading and unloading the truck requires you to hit just one button. Ultimately, what's left in the process is pure driving experience which is simply take it or leave it.

And I take it. It's simply relaxing - take a trailer, turn on the radio and drive. Sometimes that's all what you want to do. There are people around here who prefer to cruise around the map in GTA V rather than enganging in any action-packed activities. This game is exactly this but uses trucks as a main theme.

Anyway... don't expect miracles. This game has gone a long way during 10 years of its development but there are still some issues with core elements and unpolished gameplay aspects. Proper antialiasing is lacking and that's important in a game where you mostly stare at the road somewhere in the distance. Seeing all those jagged lines might get tiresome. AI is fine at best, it might behave weird on highways which is most roads (it's a trucking simulator, isn't it?). Multiplayer doesn't always work as it should, I sometimes expect desyncs especially with weather. Lighting is nice unless you enter the tunnel where it's just not right at daytime. Certain areas of the map hasn't been reworked yet and look straight bad as if taken from 2000s. Some of those issues might be minor but trust me, as you spend more and more time driving, you keep noticing these things as there is nothing else to focus at.

There are getting there. They reworked lighting, added multiplayer, they've been revamping old areas in the map. There's certainly some labor put in the game to keep it fresh. However, it takes time. A huge amount of time. For this reason I simply recommend buying this game as it is and don't expect things to be fixed. If they actually fix them, that'll be nice. But nothing's granted.

Stardew Valley is an open-ended country-life RPG! You‚Äôve inherited your grandfather‚Äôs old farm plot in Stardew Valley. Armed with hand-me-down tools and a few coins, you set out to begin your new life. Can you learn to live off the land and turn these overgrown fields into a thriving home? It won‚Äôt be easy. Ever since Joja Corporation came to town, the old ways of life have all but disappeared. The community center, once the town‚Äôs most vibrant hub of activity, now lies in shambles. But the valley seems full of opportunity. With a little dedication, you might just be the one to restore Stardew Valley to greatness!

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 (ETS2) is a great game that's been consistently updated for a decade over which SCS greatly improved the quality of their works... in fact so much so that the map has unfortunately become inconsistent with some countries looking really immersive and some looking like a port from an early 2000's game. With regards to the latter, it's primarily Poland and the United Kingdom; those two are in the base game and haven't been touched since release in 2012 and are in need of a major overhaul while Czech Republic, Slovakia, and Hungary, which were added in the first map expansion, need a solid update.

With this in mind, I would recommend folks try out American Truck Simulator (ATS) that was released in 2016 and already has had its base map overhauled to match the quality of ATS's DLC's - this way, you'll have a much more enjoyable and consistent experience compared to ETS2 quality roller-coaster.

it's a good game but not one that I'd actually recommend you buy unless you're really into trucks. the main gameplay loop consists of 
1:find a job
2:spawn at/go to location (depending on if the truck is your's or a company's)
3:drive past the 3 buildings in the capital "city" (of which 1 is a dealership and 1 is a repair shop, and the last is the one you left)
4:merge on to motorway
4.5: drive past the endless service stations and absolute barren wasteland most places seem to be
5: drive until you reach the 3 buildings in your destination
6: park, and deliver trailer (but you don't have to)
7: get paid
8:repeat process until you can afford the thing you wanted
again, interesting concept, but don't buy unless your love for trucks outweighs the boredom of driving for hours just to repay that bank loan you took out to buy a basic truck

Be a truck driver without the long hours. Starting out, you drive for someone else. Eventually you get enough money to buy your own truck so you can start your own trucking business. With only two hours in, I have not earned my own truck. I just finished my first delivery. 

Games such as these live and die on the driving mechanics. If you have played any GTA you won't have any trouble with the mechanics. Handling a big rig is another matter. I spent my first hour trying to back and turn the truck without ramming into buildings or parked cars. Once I got onto the freeway it felt like I was really driving on a freeway, something I haven't done for years (in real life I only drive in town). The game environment has a real-world look, almost photo-realistic. The mirrors actually work. The GPS works. The radio works. 

One thing I didn't like: there is no driving avatar. It looks like Caspar is driving the truck. Or maybe one of the Mythbusters are driving it with their remote. Not a big deal. It does break immersion a bit.

ETS2 is an experience.

It's a beacon of simplicity, caked in a layer of gameplay not often seen in gaming.

A simulator that allow you to run your own company. Starting from nothing and in to a europe wide enterprise. Building garages and hiring drivers to the point you can just drive around and do whatever you want since money won't be an issue.

The game features realistic driving, puts your parking skills to the test, and requires you pay attention to local speed limits and trafic laws to turn a good profit. It's by far one of the most relaxing and low energy experiences I could ever reccomend on this platform.

Get it! Even if it's just to mindlessly drive around while listening to podcasts in the background.

I heard this game was supposed to be realistic, but I disagree. I was able to move freight between the EU and Britain easily. 

Jokes aside, it's a detailed sim with a lot of polish (and Polish). Driving is super relaxing, and construction work, accidents, and road closures make the world dynamic. I do wish the management side of the game had a little more to it; logistics and supply chain management are enormously complex and there's untapped potential there.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a very interesting game but enjoyable one. I am from the United States of America and even though I have both American Truck Simulator and Euro Truck Simulator 2 I mainly play on Euro Truck Simulator 2 over American Truck Simulator. The reason is of many. First the graphics on this game are way more crisp and clean and clear rather then American Truck Simulator ( bloom way too high ). Secondly the amount of trucks we are given to use or choose from is a wide range of trucks and the options that come with each one varies. The large map scale of this game is very well done and even if you purchase the game without the ability to purchases map DLC's right away the large default map is quite impressive. Euro Truck Simulator 2 has that country background style rythum that does not come with American Truck Simulator.
this game is great for passing the time i really really really really really really really really like it

Surprisingly, it is really enjoyable just driving cargo in lorries across Europe.

IMPORTANT PERSPECTIVE, PLS READ, TLDR BOTTOM.

1. Slow progress. Updates are plenty, but content, nah. It's small things here and there. It took them 10 years to add air suspension.. And still, tons missing!

Updates are more to screw with the mods, than add things. It's like they try to quickfix their sorry ass of an game, even tho it has been 10 years. They should by now have been down to fewer updates, but more consistent and meaningfull ones.

And if something of use is coming, you can bet it'll have a prize tag, or it's just "too little, too late". 

2. The community. Their own moderators derails threads, and permbans you when talking back - SCS don't reply nor even care about their steam community ( they left it, and left an idiot to moderate that can't even shut it or keep it to topic ). The average age is 14 - 16, so maturity, is around there.

Even tho you're around trucks, it's very rare to meet an actual truckdriver.

Many of these kids, even if they aren't serverowner - they'll for sure use their time to destroy yours. Some use their time to play police, especially TMP. Keep in mind, we're talking kids who still lives at home, now supervising you and will report you to retarded staff who will ban you, for weeks.

Some kids even doctoring with evidence, and when TMP is presented with the full story, they ignore for weeks, then play it on something else, and close report. Lying, ramming and blockin guy, who sat and used his freetime to nail others to the cross? Kept driving, even tho the situation itself should have been enough for the dude to sit out for a couple of years.

Not even a "sorry" for 3 weeks ban. My feedback, ignored and trashed weeks later. 
I do opposite myself, maybe that's why my community smiles at me, without I force my community to pay, fill out shit or spam #BestCommunityEver. Not even an EULA.

DONT. USE. TMP, if you have >2 braincells and despise dramaqueens & bootlickers. Most sit and polish their trucks in their fake VTCs, playing with their shiny titles, trying to be on the next "Idiots on the road", driving same road, back and forth. 

Some sit, on their FREETIME, watching you, to rep you, for that shiny star on their "Special Deputy"-role.

If you do TMP, ALWAYS(!) record EVERY second on there. Saved me so much time and trouble.

I was a member for over 6 years, before I ever had with staff to do, and it was because some dude blocked the way on kirkenes road. For minutes, he refused to move, even staff admitted it - but still rep me after I overtook him ( I did exactly like you should IRL, I know, I'm getting paid for it ), in this case a week ban. First time in 6 years, for a fucking 10 - 20 km/h overtake with no meeting traffic, where the dude clearly didn't take his chance to drive..

I've seen people smash others, like a tornado, get banned 3 days. But what is actual harm to others, to a legal and justified overtake..

Above is TMP in a nutshell, thankfully most trash wanna be around trash, but still, you should'nt wanna be trash.

3. SCS is shit. People don't know, because SCS transparency is shitty or they're bootlickers ( too many of them! ), but SCS literally just with 1.45 (came out the other day) targeted custom servers who provide larger servers than 8, but still not as big nor cancerous as TMP, with a clientlock on everyones game, so we can't join nor see 8+ servers without modified exe-files.

It's not even in their changelog. You'd think for transparency, it should be mentioned they choose your options.. 

And they have targeted us/these servers from day 1.

So in short, they literally hardcoded into the game, what you can(t) see and play. But TMP, who has created this game horrible reputation, has made millions in the process and has the worst management I've ever meet in a game, is still here.. People literally came from that place to my server, crying, hating, screaming over how horrible TMP is on the CB. Like for hours, random people during all day, once mentioned TMP, shit just poured out. 

But then, they lost 3/4 of their community over a night. Rest of us know why, but not SCS. They pull 4k people, when ETS has over 35.000 people playing...

TMP is so bad, new people regurlarly comes in, judging my server since it's one of the bigger, as I'm one of TMP. I have worked since day one on Convoy, to be as opposite to them as human possible. Luckely, I just get shit until I tell them I'm not TMP, far from, like opposite, and they realise they can actually breathe here. People enjoyed it, till SCS shut it down - without warning. 

SCS didn't even come by and say hi before.. 

We were thousands, combined into dramafree communities ( that's amazing, in this game - like making fire outta thin air amazing ) with a strong backbone of regular people who do meetups, everyday. Standards and maturity, no BS or drama - 100% free. And we filled out, every day, 12 AM/PM, didn't matter.

If you were new and you wanted a perfect starting zone, You should've come, as so many did, to us. We'd set you up good with free cam, how to solve problems, installs, mods, be a part of convoys, races, meetups, you could advance - you had questions, we had answers.

Big problem for SCS, since they look more for paying sheep who'll happily devour their prizetag with no second thought ( forced to pay, to play full exp ), while spamming #BestCommunityEver ( observe the singular, not pluralis - they will ensure, there will only be ONE community ). 

We did, what SCS should've and what they said they would do.

4. The content SCS puts out. It's a joke in my opinion, kids in their mums basements deliver better stuff, like fenders, bullbars, lights, lightboxes, new trucks/trailers/maps etc, FOR FREE in many cases.

With way more diversity, detail and options to specific thing.

SCS were so satisfied with Iberia map and its details, but come on, Promods made even better maps 2013 than you made 2020. And promods is 100% free, 1 euro if you wanna download quick, but you could download slower for free.

Their survival is based on their monopoly on truckgames. It's gonna change one day.

I've done nearly everything in this game - freecam, savediting, mods, tweaks, bigger servers than game gives, i've gotten bugs you most never will know - but i've also been on TMP for years, as SP, as I've now played SCSMP for over a year. I've been a player, I've been staff, I now own my own community. 

I've played for over 10 year, and was reading about TMP back when it was on Moddb and only speculation was a thing. Ontop of that, I've driven trucks for soon 8 years IRL.

If it's in this game, I've most likely tried it to the extent I understand it and use it, or know enough to be able to help myself or others further. 3000 hours, i've explored this game as widely possible ( and further than SCS even ) and SCS could have been decent, but their recent changes and their shitty practices with content, restrictions and their aim - it's disgraceful and I feel ashamed I've paid their salaries.

I've spent around 2k hours into my community the last 12 months. Nearly 24/7 work, ontop of 40h+ job. Lost over a night, by the very creator of the game I paid for.

How they still allow TMP to exist, for all shit they STILL spread (while making millions!), but kill communities built on passion and love, who sits and help people globally for 100% free. Unbelievable.

10 years, I could make whole magazines of SCS/TMPs stupidity.

Don't make the same mistake, and if you must, buy only the standard game on sale and start researching how to obtain the DLC's another way. ( *cough* Youtube *cough* ).

Over 12 months, thousands of hours invested and thousands on thousands of players - and not a single negative reaction to my server. Not even the other similar servers. But we had to go. TMP tho, leaves scar on your community and bad taste in mouth, still here.. 

I do not support a game developer, who works against its own players and community.

(English evaluation, 90% by Google Translate) I've played this game for 200+ hours and I think:
1. Although the picture quality is good, it lacks in many details (such as road reflections in rainy days, road bumps, physics, weather details, etc.)
2. The shifting logic of the automatic transmission is rubbish, I had to set a key to switch between manual and automatic transmission mode
3. The cursor cannot be moved out of the game when it is paused, or there is no way to put ETS2 in the background, which has always been a problem.
4. After the multimedia key (previous, play/pause, next) is pressed, neither the music software in the background nor the radio function in the game can switch songs. Do I need to set shortcut keys?
5. In many cases, the mechanics or principles of the game have not changed, and the update is only the map or vehicle update. Even if the mod author does not need to change anything, it is judged to be incompatible. As a result, some mods need to be constantly updated. Both the author and the player are tortured. Wouldn't 
 SCS Software also improve the game's own truck?
Summary: It's fun, but there are many small details that really affect the game experience

I really recommend playing this game if you like driving games, or maybe even if you don't like driving games. It's really fun and REALLY beautiful game. If you have a high end device i really recommend to go to settings and change the graphics to high or even ultra. By far one of the most beautiful games I've ever seen. It also has a lot to do. [h1] Wanted to like this but it is BS [/h1]

I really tried. I gave this shit numerous tries. This game is great on paper. But due to bad game design I have lost so much progress over the 90hrs that I am not willing to put out with this BS anymore. Fanboys will call me bad at driving, but whatever.

[h2] IDIOTIC AI [/h2]
AI drivers are literally blind and ram into you while you are in the middle of the turn or coming out of a yard/parking lot. Numerous times I have double-checked the road is empty, just for an AI driver to spawn in, ram into my truck and not only make ME pay the "crash offence" price, it sometimes even damaged my truck or trailer.

[h2] GETTING STUCK IN TEXTURES [/h2]
This is why I lost my last 2,5hrs of driving. Was doing an online job (if you crash, turn vehicle over or get stuck you lose the job). When turning to a narrow road I miscalculated and trailer touched the siderail. Normally it is not an issue you just back up a little and do it correctly.

But this time the trailer went through the guard rail partially so I could not go back. Only way was to go forward onto the narrow bridge, just to find out both ways out of that bridge are closed. Lots of traffic behind me made it impossible to reverse and bridge was so narrow I could not turn around.

And this happened to me numerous times where you get stuck in texture, or blocked by AI vehicles making it impossible to get out of the situation.

Out of my 90hrs I lost good 30 just on BS like this. Each ride is a dice roll whether you gonna finish it. With odds being stacked against you. And single player missions where you can scum save, do not count towards progress in World of Trucks so why would you play those?

[h2] LIGHTS ARE A JOKE [/h2]
Basic truck light can't illuminate for shit so unless you spend fuckload of money on extra lights, you have to use GPS at nights or you will miss the turn easily as you can't see anything except 1m in front of your truck. And just hope it is not raining!

After 130 hours, I finally feel qualified to write a review for this. All I can say this, thank god there‚Äôs a demo, because if I hadn‚Äôt played that I probably wouldn‚Äôt have ever given this game a go. 

I had no interest I trucks whatsoever. Yet, within 5 minutes of playing the demo I felt a very strange mix of feelings - giddy excitement at just how big the game world is (especially will all the DLCs), and genuine fear of crashing as the physics felt so realistic even using an Xbox controller. And that is the thing - if you have any interest in any kind of simulator game at all, I‚Äôd be astonished if you don‚Äôt love this game. It‚Äôs the only simulator game I know of which has actually managed to mix the simulation side of things (great physics, wonderfully detailed scenery) with the ‚Äòtycoon‚Äô style business side of things, which gives your journeys actual meaning. 

It‚Äôs probably the most relaxing game I own, especially since you can listen to real internet radio stations or your own music/podcasts whilst driving. You get a real sense of place and can experience some spectacular sunsets and sunrises as you drive from one country to another. 

The scale of the map is obviously not 1:1, and it‚Äôs true that some of the cities lack character (especially UK and German which are the oldest countries in the game) as they are mostly just made up of the various cargo yards and service stations, but there are also some genuinely authentic feeling cities (I think some of the French ones are superb) and also little towns that you end up driving through randomly which adds to the realism. 

I just think everyone should try this game, even if you‚Äôre convinced you‚Äôll hate it (I was pretty sure I would) for the money it‚Äôs one of the best games I‚Äôve ever played.

I played this game (a lot more - ahoy mates ;> ) instead of studying for college exams.

[b] Beginning [/b]

The game welcomes you with a nice loading animation. You choose your character avatar, there are many of them, but they are simple. Create your company and choose one of the few logos. Choose the truck that you like the most and take training on it. At first, you drive other people's trucks, and as you earn experience, new longer routes will open up for you, for which more rewards rely. You will not even notice how in a couple of hours you will make trips to neighboring countries, instead of between cities.

[b] Gameplay [/b]

The game has acquired a bunch of mechanics all the time: air suspension, which if you do not lower it, you won't be able to hitch a trailer, power windows, wiper modes, traffic accidents due to which your planned route will have to change, changing the rigidity of the cabin and stabilizing the trailer. Also, you can take a loan from the bank and buy yourself a new truck that you dreamed about and go to private orders or expand the company by buying 1 or even 2 cheap trucks and hiring drivers for them. The game won't let you get bored with its radio, which has more than 40 stations, I think everyone will find a suitable wave for themselves and will enjoy the road. The road in the game is too monotonous for me, the same interchanges that meet one after another. In the game, you can adjust the amount of precipitation, which is a very convenient feature. If you are used to seeing rain more often than dry weather outside your window and vice versa, then in the game you can customize everything for yourself. When you are already stand firm and can afford the truck of your dreams, the game will not deprive you. Many variations of the engine, chassis, standard hood amplifiers and beacons on them. For more colorful skins, wheels and accessories, you will have to pay for the DLC. Absolutely the same with trailers, game has almost all types of trailers in the world.

[b] Traffic [/b]

The AI in the game is very well done, they use turn signals, they don‚Äôt run through red lights and they know how to brake urgently. If you have an emergency situation along the middle of the road, then when the hazard lamps are turned on, the traffic will not drive up close to you from behind, but will leave room for maneuver. I have noticed more than once that the AI is trying in every possible way to help the player when leaving the site of the nook companies by stopping and letting you go ahead. The police are present in the game, they do not have designated places where they could stand, so you meet them on the road. If you drive on the highway more than 90 km / h and the police catch up with you, they will fine you in 95 percent of cases. If you violate and drive 120 km/h and catch up with the police, who goes 110 km/h overtaking them, you will be fined in 80% of cases, but if you slow down and follow them at 110 km/h, then you won't be fined.

[b] DLC [/b]

The game has accumulated a lot of DLC, most of them are coloring pages of different countries and are simply themed. There are tuning packs that add many parts and accessories of a specific brand of truck. DLC for expanding maps has been in the game for a long time and they have already accumulated, considering the size of additional maps. Due to the huge number of DLCs, it may seem that they are expensive if you want everything at once, but individually they cost quite sane money. [u] Therefore, the developers are SCS, not Ubisoft. [/u]

[b] Online [/b]

The game has a partner "Truckers MP" with which you can drive in multiplayer with friends and players from all over the world, however this is just a mod and there is no traffic inside. Not so long ago, the developers added their own internal multiplayer with traffic. Playing with a friend has become much more enjoyable when there is traffic. You can create an open server and wait for new people and make new friendship, or make a closed lobby and arrange a private convoy of up to 10 people, and that's all with traffic!

[b] Conclusion [/b]

If you are a fan of the auto industry, auto simulators and want to safely drive around Europe, then the game is worth the money. The developers were able to make a game where you can relax, immerse yourself in your thoughts and watch a beautiful picture. Personally, I liked the game for its simplicity, which lies in a bunch of little things.

P.S. at the time of writing the review, I have played more than 3k hours on the second account.

I'ts a very good truck simulator that is completely ruined by few frickin annoying technical problems that creators don't seem bother to fix, like AI or collission detection:
- other cars will drive straight into you when you f.e. try to leave compound,
- while I was making a narrow turn bus literally drove straight into my trailer like it wasn't there,
- roundabouts in the cities are a Russian roulette minigame,
- while you drive along highway other drivers will change lanes and hit you,
- got 25% damage to my truck when I dinked into a caravan trailer that was moving on lane next to me (so relative speed speed so around 15-20 kmh),
- I can't even recall how many times my truck just flew into the air when I scraped on the barriers between lanes on highway ending up with 60-80% damage,
- the uneven traffic generator: you can get massive traffic in the middle of nowhere at 3 AM and absolutely nobody at the same place in the middle of the day,
- sometimes complete f*cked up traffic generator: I got stuck while making turn at junction in industrial area at about 5 AM and suddenly there were several cars in all of streets around me, so I couldn't even back up or move forward without hitting anyone,
- I built and maxed garages in every city available in the basic game only to find out that... there are not enough drivers in the game to fill all the vacancies.

I quite liked the first game, it was simple, it was boring, it was pointless, this one is more complicated, in many ways far better, but the creators seems to be completely focused on selling DLCs and some silly graphic improvements than fixing the basics of the game.

SCS pretty much have truck sim sewn up with this and ATS. 

ETS2 is probably the best starting point for any would be virtual trucker. Not only has it forged the blueprint of all of SCS offerings since, it's probably the most complete of all of them. With the base game offering a fairly substantial map of Europe and numerous expansions. On top of that there are literally hundreds of MODs that have been developed over the last decade. Ranging from liveries to entire new maps.

So what is so appealing about SCS's offerings? Well they are the perfect blend of accessibility and sim. From a keyboard to a full wheel set up there is plenty that can be gotten from ETS2(and ATS) whatever your skill level.On top of that SCS have rendered some fantastic scenery with recognisable landmarks. Which makes ETS2 the perfect game to slap on a pod cast and just chill as you cruise across the continent.

ETS2 is regularly on sale, so do keep a look out. However despite being almost a decade old now, it sill holds up even at its full price.  SCS still drop updates for the game and have new DLC planned.
I have close to 8000 hours in ETS2 for a reason. It's a brilliant game.

Already have 8 garages and nearly $10 million in ATS. ETS2 is a little, just a little , tougher. Have 6 garages but are earning at over EUR 1.1 million per week. Best things in ETS2 are that gameplay is on the one hand intense with time, traffic and tiredness being the enemy, and, on the other hand, is relaxed and immersive, with places to go, things to do, and , best of all, you can build up your business with little problem. The following are highly recommended:
- upgrade the trucks to reward the best drivers. When the company is doing well, upgrade everything before buying more garages.
- buy trailers only if you really want to- there is little business sense as the jobs you can do get limited.
- get your truck report by fast travel after each job.
- you can tone down or turn off the annoyances such as weather events, diversions, road events, fines for speeding and fines crashing into others. But speed limit warnings and fatigue simulation should be there. Damage cannot be turned off. 
- the best roads are in Norway but they are usually two lane only.
- the best highways are, of course, in Germany, but the speed limit is 80 kmph
- there are way too many toll booths in France. But the max speed of 90kmph is there on all highways.
- crossing Britain is really easy as all the towns are bypassed by the highways.
- there is really great fun in doing ferry crossings. You can drive onto the ship usually. The crossing takes place off-game but the time on ferries counts towards rest stops.
- things I like- crossing the bridges from Denmark to Sweden, the winding roads in Corsica and Sicily, driving through the town in Vienna, looking for landmarks like the gherkin in London, Eiffel in Paris, Munich Stadium (beautiful at night), the massive topiary bull on the approach to Madrid, the roundabouts inside the tunnels in Norway. Always blow the horn in the alps tunnels to hear the echoes.

Great fun. Buy all the DLCs.

There is so many different ways to play. 1. You can play it realistically, following traffic laws, stopping to sleep and using your turn signal. 2. You can turn off laws and drive dangerously, still trying not to hit other cars. 3. You can install a mod where your truck does not take damage from the easy to use workshop and mod manager. Now you can drive down highways ramming every car off the road just so and IKEA can get carbonated water. The map and DLCs are beautiful and well thought out. 10/10

Absolutely the best driving simulator I have ever encountered. I think the fact that it is a single game that gets updates over many years is one of the reasons it is so well-made. Compare that to driving simulators that release a "new" game every few years with pretty much the same content but with an updated year in the name, a few features removed and added, a new yet not bigger map and an inevitable UI overhaul.
Euro Truck Simulator 2 offers an immensely huge map (I bought all of the map expansion DLCs and the base game during a sale for dirt cheap) with satisfying roads and a huge variety of trucks to purchase. It also offers valuable customizability and flexibility in the controls and settings. Euro Truck Simulator 2 is THE game to relax on and clear your mind. I even managed to use it as a "tactical distraction" years ago for memorizing vocabulary without noticing that an hour passed and I actually made progress.
Thanks to the game being "old", it gathered a really great and dedicated modding community that comes up with a lot of mods that really enhance the driving experience by a lot such as mods that significantly improve the graphics and the textures, add AI vehicles and change AI behaivour. People even created web-apps that connect to your game and allow you to utilize an old tablet that's been laying around for years as an actual dashboard for your truck!
Something that you can find in great mods by the community that I would like to see implemented in the base game is the ability to adjust the traffic intensity since the traffic on the roads often doesn't feel satisfying enough.
A huge turn-off for me, regarding mods, is that you cannot play multiplayer (Native or TruckersMP) with mods that do not affect the game but only make local changes such as graphics mods since it either is completely impossible on TruckersMP or on native multiplayer requires everyone you play with to have the exact same mods, which is very inconvenient and often impossible with local mods that are not available on the Steam Workshop.
Another worth-mentioning point is that while the AI feels pretty authentic on single-player, on TruckersMP, which does not contain AI vehicles at all, you will be driving through empty roads and seeing a truck every minute or so, possibly driving on the opposite side of the road. When you do encounter other people driving around, they will most likely be stuck at some weird intersection in a situation that would not happen in real-life.
Something I appreciated as a kid, playing this years ago for a couple of hundreds of hours is that the graphics are not insane and your computer or even laptop are very likely to be able to deliver satisfying performance, but at the same time if you have a more powerful machine - you can download mods that significantly enhance the graphics and it no longer feels like an "old" game.
I play this game with my mouse which is surprisingly comfortable for me and encouraged me to use mouse steering on other driving simulators as well, even though they don't manage to do it as well as Euro Truck Simulator 2 does since it has a setting called "Steering non-linearity" which I have never encountered in any other driving simulator and makes the steering using a mouse make much more sense as it adapts the sensitivity of the mouse according to the speed of the truck. That way, you can make more precise corrections to the steering wheel on a highway, but also comfortably navigate inside cities.
Driving in this game feels the closest I know to real-life driving, and I wish other driving simulators could use the same base of the game and its features instead of creating their own.

I find this game relaxing and calming to play in my humble opinion. HOWEVER... When doing a 130,000 euro 56 hour drive, and at the end... I DON'T want to loose 80,000 euros in damage because I touched but a petulant curb and my employers Truck flipped over... Overall I'm satisfied.

Cons:

- Does not model road conditions, which can be bad or good. Some countries, especially parts of Eastern Europe, don't have well maintained roads.

This game is okay. 

I mean okay in the sense that it's only okay if you have no friends and play alone in your sad, dark, and depressing basement owned by your mum. You can easily spend several hours driving pathetic virtual trucks and not notice the piss leaking onto the carpet below from one of your bottles. 

The real pain starts when you decide to play with friends- or worse, on truckersmp. Your gaming session will start of with the comforting delusion that you'll be having a nice time with the homies. But, do not be fooled: doom, pain, suffering, and the overwhelming desire to off yourself awaits you. You'll be satisfied in a happy clappy universe on your rainbow-coloured unicorn of delusion before you spiral into the deepest pits of humanity and helplessly fall into a depressing path of destruction. You will breathe pure fury and your eyes will seek only for murder. Your breath - which only moments before consisted of the most vile scent of cheetos - turns into an ever-increasing fireball of pure hatred. Your mum will enter your basement to let you know your chicken nuggets are ready but you will only hear the taunting laughter of a toddler. You will wreak havoc and everything you touch will turn into ash. You will not see the devil as for you are the devil. You will not be the personification of evil as for you are the evil. You will assure that pain does not become a concept to people but rather becomes their only reality as they beg you for release. Your name no longer becomes recognisable to you and you'll only respond to the crying of those who you torture. Your face warps into a disfigured Guy Fawkes mask. 

And then you'll call it a day and repeat everything tomorrow. 10/10

This game on its own is fantastic. It nails what it was made to do with that being driving a truck around Europe.

Now I started playing this game on keyboard and it was pretty bad to be honest so I spent around 5 hours on keyboard before grabbing an old Xbox 360 controller and using that which made the experience 10x better, I could smoothly change lanes turning wasn't all or nothing I had the ability to turn smoothly.
At the point I had put around 50 hours in and then learned of how much this game had been modded both on and off the steam workshop, there are new maps, more detailed version of the vanilla map, new trucks, cars, AI diversity, Lighting, Graphics you name it and it's probably been modded there is also a mod which turns the game into an MMO basically.

Now when I got to 100 hours I decided to take the plunge and got myself a wheel, pedals and shifter which just improved the game, even more, I have perfect input for small changes, and the force feedback makes even the smallest of bumps important to look out for, the control of gears while taking heavy cargo up a hill or offroad it's just amazing and add in the fact that you can play this game in VR! The immersion is just out of this world.

If you have ever wanted to drive a truck around Europe but not leave the comfort of your own home then this game is for you and if you get bored of driving around Europe hop on over to America with American Truck Simulator both games are the exact same thing but each has their own atmosphere around them with how the laws are, roads you drive on, trucks, AI traffic, Cargo you take and the trailers that are used.

This is a godlike game and a must have if you love sim driving/racing games and just want to relax while in a VC for hours.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

When my friends chose to buy random FPS games (in which you shoot everyone else to get the #1 position), I chose to buy this. And I haven't regretted buying it a bit.
So what's this game about? Well, driving trucks. That's it. No hopping out of the driver's seat, no thinking about when you'll have lunch or dinner. [i]Just driving trucks[/i]. 
You keep driving your truck across the continent of Europe. You start with delivering cargo on the company's truck ([i]this is a good time to test various truck designs[/i]). You slowly make enough money to buy your own truck, or just get a loan instead. You make more deliveries and your rating (and XP) slowly increases. You learn to maneuver tight corners when delivering big construction equipment or even boats. You slowly find yourself wanting to transition from just being a truck driver to becoming an entrepreneur of sorts. You purchase a 2nd truck and hire another driver. You then realise that even though the driver is working and bringing in profits, you can never actually 'see' the driver or that truck in person!! Even when the truck is parked in the garage, you still can't see the truck in the garage!
Ok, so that's how you have become a smallish entrepreneur. Then slowly you begin climbing the ladder. More truck, more hired drivers, more places explored, all that stuff. The 'mouse steering' option kinda doesn't seem like enough, you begin to crave for something more. Something better. Something more realistic. A 'steering wheel', to be precise. In short, you begin to fall in love with the game.

Alright, that's enough storytelling from my side, now let's get to the pros and cons.
Pros:
1. [b]It's the kind of game that brings peace[/b] to my life. Whenever I get stressed out, I fire up this game. There's something about peacefully driving a truck on cruise control across a beautiful 6-lane highway. It calmes me down.
2. [b]There's no end to this game.[/b] It seems like a real job. It's not like you put in x no. of hours or complete y chapters and everything's complete. Even if you seem to be at the 'end' of the game because you got a garage full of fully upgraded trucks and have explored the full map, SCS will push out an update/DLC that'll get you back on the road sooner than you think.
3. [b]The options and places to explore are endless.[/b] You think that you've explored 100% of the map? Think again. Go back, I'm sure you get atleast a dozen places you haven't explored yet. Go explore them now!
4. [b]Exceptional compatibility[/b]. Let me elaborate this a bit. I bought this game on Steam back when I used Windows 10. But since I'm kinda a tech nerd, I recently said Windows bye-bye and made the switch to Linux. And guess what? Euro Truck Simulator 2 [b]works on Linux flawlessly and with no crashes[/b].
I also got it running on the M1 macBook Pro one of my relatives bought a while ago, and this game ran there without issues as well.
Also this game supports low-end hardware pretty well. I played it on my old trusty Intel Pentium G2030 with 4GB of RAM. It ran fine on low settings & 720p. This game seems to work just about everywhere. [b]Hats off to SCS for pulling this off![/b] :)
I can't recommend this game enough. Go on. Buy this game when it's on sale. Get your friends on it. It's well worth it.
It gets a [b]10/10[/b] from my side. Have fun!
