Euro Truck Simulator 2 is one of those games that you don't expect it to be as fun as it is.  I play a fair amount of racing games on my sim wheel and this game has its own charm.  Even though the braking, acceleration, and turning are all slow, your heart rate gets up as you plow through intersections and try to find the exact limits this truck can perform without receiving tickets, accidents, and major damage.  When you want to relax, you can drive the truck like a responsible person and enjoy the scenery.  Either way, you're building your trucking business and driving across different parts of Europe.  I have the Going East DLC as well and that has been really nice to have too.  Highly recommend this game to anyone hoping to have fun in a slightly unorthodox way.

The very first SCS game that I played was the original Euro Truck Simulator; and goodness did I play the heck out of it.

Discovered this game awhile after, and there is a night and day difference in the gameplay!

There are THOUSANDS of MILES of roads to explore across numerous European states, as well as several different makes and models of trucks to drive, too. The attention to detail in the countries and vehicles is SUPERB, for the most part. The graphics and landscape is beautiful, and never struggles to impress.

The one thing that this game (and American Truck Simulator) is lacking is soft body physics. It's a little boring ramming into something and having the truck just stop and not obliterate itself into a million pieces. Other than that it's a good game and I highly recommend it!

I'm highly recommending the game so far (after 22 hours played). As for most of the past 20 years and counting, I've mainly played FPS games, however, I got this game as a recommendation from a friend who's got around 800hrs on it and told me he finds it relaxing. I've kinda made fun of him for playing it, so figured I'd give it a shot. Doesn't hurt to try a new game to play.

To my surprise, the game is extremely relaxing, as I put my headphones on and blast on music and then truck away for hours. For someone that even hates driving IRL, this game has made me calmer in traffic and feel less stressed in both the game and real life.

The game itself has amazing functions such as opening your shop, hiring drivers, buying trucks, or just driving around for fun. You can control the weather & random events on the roads as well which is nice.
So if you're looking for a game that you can chill with friends and just have a game or want to calm down, this is a game that you should buy IMHO.

Life Changing. Only way I can describe this game.
My time used to be taken up producing websites, creating spreadsheets and fixing computers for friends and family. But ever since I purchased ETS2 I have been living in a whole new world. First was the purchase of a wheel, pedals and gearstick, soon followed by a third screen, and before I knew it a 4th screen. Not happy sitting at my computer desk, this led to designing and building my own simulation rig. My old i7 was doing okay, but the Nvidia 960 graphics card was being pushed to its limits, so last month I raided the penny jar and now have a powerful i9 10th edition with an Nvidia GTX 3060. I've now fitted my old CB (minus aerial at the moment), obtained a real van instrument panel, and purchased an Arduino board to make it all work (once I find someone who understands it better than me) plus a few USB joystick controllers and a load of buttons to finish of the build of the dashboard.

I'm planning to stream and create Youtube videos, so have just fitted a professional Mic and connected better cameras, so things are nowhere near how they used to be.

I run both ETS2 and ATS, but I don't know many, so despite attempting to join the convoy section I have yet to experience it with others. so if you are hosting a convoy session, then please feel free to invite me.

This was my favourite game from when I was a kid and I had it on the disc version. Now, I'm starting to pick up this game again and it's so much fun. Euro Truck Simulator 2 has got to be one of my most favourite games I've ever played. I don't even know why it's my favourite game, but it just is. Nothing can beat it.

Maybe the best open world game I've ever played, along with it's American cousin. I run it on a 500 dollar laptop, WASD keyboard and it's rarely a problem for me. The DLCs make a very large map and there's a strong modding community, which, a year after I've started playing, I'm still finding great new stuff on often. There was the option of a free preview for me a year ago, highly suggest you run that first, mostly to see how your hardware stacks up. Even my 5 year old laptop could run a low res, low fps version. Highly Recommend!

This is one of the best simulator games I've ever played. Looks great, works fine, has enough variation, good realism, no steep learning curve. I just like to drive and look around in all these great good looking environments/countries. I've had many car accidents just because I was too much looking at and enjoying the landscape instead of keeping the eyes on the road.

I would enjoy it more if there were a bit more local roads. So a less high percentage of highways. What also sometimes frustrates me is that when the game updates, it sends my truck back to the garage. I understand that it is good for stability, it is safe to do it that way. But it is not nice to lose the progress on a job. A solution could be to allow the user to decide when to update (e.g. update after current cargo is delivered). Not sure if that is possible.

I have been a long time player of ETS2 and first bought it on disk back in 2012. 

I came back to playing ETS2 back in 2018 and still play regularly. 

I love this simulator and find both its community and customer service excellent. 

I‚Äôve live streamed many of my gameplays and have all the map DLCs combined with supported mods such as ProMods - this simulator is amazing. 

Best played with the Logitech G29, shifter and pedals with the combination of tobii eye 5, giving this simulator a great immersive experience. 

During lockdown this was the only way for me to travel and explore Europe. Having been to several of the places in game in real life. I appreciate the attention to details by the developers. 

The more recent ability to convoy with other real players is a great asset. 

Highly recommended!

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a [b]great game[/b] to play alone (there's also plenty of mods!) as well as with friends. The developers are still delivering great free updates as well as map expansion DLCs (which are mostly cheap during any Steam sale) and other contents - they have released an official online "co-op" mode with mod support just this year!
I've never really played any driving simulator or anything similar before. Now, after more than 200 hours of playing vanilla, modded singleplayer, and the awesome community-made inofficial multiplayer, I can't help but recommend EVERYONE to give this game a try.
You won't regret it.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

I owe this game a review since this is the game I played the longest so far. It still amazes me that this game has captured my heart 7 years ago and does not want to let it go. For most people it would seem that driving a truck would get boring quickly. However all that work the game developer (SCS Software) has put into this game has been keeping it alive and well for the last 9 years. And definitely it's not the end. New content (i.e. trucks, locations) being constantly added, some of the existing stuff being revised and revamped, interesting community challanges every now and then do not go unnoticed by the devoted community of this game. Huge library of mods for this game also requires mentioning. Some of the modders have been updating their mods for almost as long as the game exists. This just shows that the game is truly unique. And the best part is that it's never too late to become part of this community and experience all the (surprising) fun this game has to offer.

I started playing this game because a friend recommended it to me and because it was in discount, and I must say... I LOVE IT.

I was sceptical at first because the game was released back in 2012, but the fact that it is still being updated really blows my mind. SCS put such a level of detail and love in everything that I'm becoming addicted to it. 
I also thought it could become pretty repetitive, but it doesn't.

Yes, there are some things that are clearly from a 2012 game, like the vegetation, but the stunning view while driving distracts you from noticing it. Also, consider that you're usually driving at least 50km/h, so you won't usually stare at the vegetation.
The multiple DLCs available help in keeping the game fun, mainly the map DLC. But you can have a lot of fun even with the base game (I played for ~36h and I only recently bought a DLC, Italia DLC)

Would totally recommend it, considering that you'll often find it at ~5‚Ç¨

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is highly recommended. Here's my review with time logged at Level 13 with 7 of 81 achievements complete. Game was purchased on sale and I just downloaded the Scandinavian DLC so I wanted to share my thoughts to those interested.

I was concerned about trucking doldrums but the tutorial paved the way to my entertainment experience. Starting out is a challenge and when you get your own shop and hire drivers you now have management tasks. You can assign drivers your own trailers and train them the way you want. My graphics work well, soundtrack is good, and game play cool. You will struggle financially of course but your as drivers improve so does your income. The sleep required option does compliment the simulator with the requirement burden. You  can borrow from the bank and have loans active so be careful. Your ability to drive in the UK will be tested adapting to the left lane as well. I'm still in business. Drivers wanted. Have fun!...

This is one of those games that you pick up when you don't really want to do anything too complicated, filling quite a niche. If like me, you loved the whole hitching a rig to a trailer in GTAV then this is one for you. The trucks look great and the physics can be adjusted from basic acceleration / steering to the full H shifter experience. The customisation features for the trucks and trailers is very in-depth but you'll find yourself spending a lot of your hard earned cash upgrading your first rig.

Sadly the graphics aside from the trucks are not that great and the motorway layouts - particularly in the UK cause a lot of frustration as to how horribly inaccurate they are. For example most junctions have no slip road. The inside lane simply veers off, sometimes only leaving one lane of motorway! Most of the layouts in Europe are not like this so not sure why the devs only did this to the UK? Another bug bear is the traffic offences, where you'll occasionally get fined for improper headlight use in the daytime even though they're switched off. 

Then there's the cities. Ok, I get this is just a simulation and has to be scaled down, but the cities in this game are smaller than most villages in real life and really takes the edge off the satisfaction this game produces. 

Overall, I recommend getting this but only when it's on sale.

Amazing game. Entertaining, relaxing, therapeutic...

You may think (like I did since the game was released) that this isn't something people could be into, but you'd be wrong. Even if sitting behind a virtual steering wheel all day hauling tons of cargo seems like a waste of time, this game really delivers when it comes to the overall simulation experience, and that's what hooks you.

You'll learn about trucks and truck modifications, Europe's geography, many types of trailers and different cargo types, fuel consumption and fuel economy, and lots more. Not only you are given the truck driving simulation experience, this game also provides that much needed (for most people) sense of progress, be allowing you to build your own truck empire from the ground up, creating your own company and hiring people to work for you. It's just amazing.

If you like to play alone and spend hours in front of your monitor with nothing but your thoughts, maybe listen to some music, some stand-up comedy, or even watch a movie on a second monitor... This is the game for you.

Wait... You don't like playing alone? Well... You can also play with friends or random people through convoy lobbies or even play at a much larger scale on multiplayer lobbies without AI traffic! In that case, this is also the game for you.

This is a game that's...almost 10 years old.
This game...has rather modest system requirements. Doesn't normally bode well to outstanding graphics or features. 
This is a game about...trucks. Arguably, not typically something to get excited about.

And yet...the thousands of reviews for this game are "Overwhelmingly Positive". How?

Well, I haven't played this game that much yet, especially compared to other people (many have put in literally hundreds - and some even thousands - of hours), but I can see why.

The low system requirements mean that you don't need a mega powerful computer to run it. If playing on a laptop, the battery will probably last longer than if playing most other games, too. 

Sure, the graphics do betray the age of the game (both in-game and in the menus), but they're not too bad either imho.

Driving such big and heavy machinery is surprisingly satisfying; being able to manoeuvre this thing - especially parking it - is no mean feat, which adds to the satisfaction when you are able to get it right. Moreover, you get so much functionality - ability to turn on/off lights, wipers, indicators, open/close windows, set cruise control, view fuel consumption...for geeks like me, this is absolute heaven. 

There are some good challenges that spice up the gameplay - keep in mind that this is also a business sim/tycoon game. And it's quite realistic - you can even get fined if you exceed the seed limit!

You also get to transport many types of cargo (and need to adjust your driving style accordingly), and see many sceneries across different countries. And the numerous DLCs further serve to add more [i]good[/i] content (i.e. these DLCs are not merely cash grabs to make a quick buck off of players like you and me, but are actually made with care).

Finally, this game has garnered a large and helpful community, which has also enabled the existence of numerous great mods, and new content is [i]still[/i] being released. This, along with frequent live broadcasts demonstrating the new features, are evidence that this game is made with love. The cherry on the cake is that this game is very reasonably priced, especially during sales (which occur quite frequently). You can't ask for much more than that.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a game about being a truck driver, mostly in Europe and your goal is to make a company.

ETS 2 has a really relaxed gameplay, which also quite addictive. You basically choose a delivery and make your way there with your truck, meanwhile you need to manage your vehicle and your company later in the game. You can also level up in different delivery types which let you have different cargo, which also needs different equipment too. In general, this is a simple, but great idea, but probably the only thing I can nitpick on, is that the base game has not too many places to go and those doesn't look that different from each other. Of course, at first this is not big of a deal, but later it will be more noticeable, where you get into 4 different cities which has somewhat the same layout. Thankfully this issue is somewhat fixable with the DLCs, which is not that cheap sometimes, but those definitely add some bonus content, which makes the game a hundred times more likeable.

Next is the graphics, which for 2012 is all right. In general, most of the models looks decent, just like the environment, but it has a plastic feeling just looking at it in my opinion. With a few mods this can be also changed, but for me, this is not the strongest point of the game, but definitely not a horrible one either.

The sound design is also really good. There are not too many music in the game, except if you listen a radio, but there is no need. If you want to listen something, go ahead, but the game give you the minimum sound you need, which are not annoying and perfectly fits for the game.

About the controls, I won't lie, it was bit difficult for me to get into and understand which button do what. It's not easy, but you can get used to it and you can check the settings all the time. There are lot of actions you can do, so it's definitely worth it to check these.

At last, the story. I will be straightforward, the game has none, and this is not a problem. You don't need it actually, you make your own story with your journeys, going around the world and you don't need more motivation, than to just make your deliveries between countries.

For me, Euro Truck Simulator 2 wasn't and interesting game at first, but throughout the years, the game has so much plus content and I didn't even mentioned the convoy mode, which makes the whole experience just better. This is the game which I pick, if I want to chill for a moment, just to drive out and it's perfect for that, but also you can put into a lot of effort and make your truck company empire. This is definitely the game you need to check, and I can absolutely recommend it to you. For 20‚Ç¨, you could even pick it for the full price, but get the DLCs on sale.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a fantastic game. I'm so happy to have found it - and decided to play, as I had it in my arsenal for a year or two. It's got everything - a need for speed, a need for skill, drama, tension, you actually care, and the devilishly simple premise turns out to be full of twists and turns - literally.

This title blends strategy and simulation in a unique fashion. Some games manage to pull this off, but most either focus too much on one or the other. Yet, somehow, the seemingly most boring concept that could be has been designed into a thrilling, captivating game. Really splendid. I hear there's also American Truck Simulator. Well, you know what that means. A real convoy!

Cheers.

With 500+ hours invested, I can say with confidence that:

- Truck goes BRR
- Crash goes BRR
- Cash go POOF

But other than that, the game is a solid 10/10 driving simulator.
When you drive, you feel the weight you are pulling, you feel every corner you went a bit too fast in and the scenery is truly beautiful (if your PC can handle the settings).

The game also still regularly receives free updates like new truck models, updated textures, updated road networks and for those with a bit of cash there also tends to be a new DLC in the works constantly giving new countries and new landscapes to traverse.

For anyone interested in a good driving game, this is almost a must.

You got two choices when playing this game IMO:

1.- Actually following traffic rules and being a good truck driver.

2.- Remove speed limit and go 100 km/h swerving in traffic to get from point A to point B as fast as possible.

All jokes aside, the game has incredible graphics, options to upload your own music files to listen as a radio, in case you don't use streaming services on the background; has a ton of truck modification options, both for tuning it for better performance, and to make the interior more cozy to your liking.

Honestly an absolute 10/10 for a game to just sit down, relax, and enjoy the scenery as you drive through some pretty accurate European interstate and highways.

Ever since I've tried the ETS 1 many many years ago, I've always wanted to try it with the steering wheel controller. So much so that I made a make shift steering wheel using the mouse. 
But now, I have finally managed to buy a Thrustmaster TX, and the first thing I did was purchase the ETS 2.
It might not give the excitement or the adrenaline rush like the other racing games, but there is something about this game that I really can't explain. Something that makes me want to choose it over the other games.

The recent update to the force feedback is also worthy of a praise and has significantly improved the gameplay.

Very good trucking simulation. It is fun to play for simulation fans aswell as for casual players.
Although i would recommend buying some DLCs alongside the base game. The "Euro Truck Simulator 2 Essentials" bundle is a decent choice and worth the money. It adds more countries to the map and some other stuff. 
Every few months a new DLC gets released with new countries and new roads.

If you want to play with friends there is a official multiplayer mode where you can pick a destination and drive in a convoy with friends. However if you want to play multiplayer with up to 4800 players on 1 server i would recommend TruckersMP its not official but it is the better multiplayer mode in my opinion.

Euro Truck is an amazing game with endless combinations of Trucks and Trailers. If this game didn't have the ability to have mods, it would have been a dead game for a long long time ago, but here we are today, playing it after 9 years and the community is alive and well and the mod community is amazing and they are always contributing to the benefit of Euro Truck Simulator 2 players and gives the Developers some inspiration to add the mods to a new version of the game and have it as a feature in the game. While the American Truck Simulator community is not as strong as the Euro Truck Simulator 2, they are both equally great games, from the long highways to the small country roads of France and Scandinavia, Euro Truck will never fail to make you happy.

I've somehow achieved the mark of 450 hours and I really have no idea how. It's been almost a year and a half since I bought this game and somehow it's been the game I most play. Does it have an interesting gameplay? No. Is it boring? Yes. Have I spent dozens of dollars on DLCs even though I could've just downloaded a map from the Internet? Yes. At the end of the day this is an amazing game if you have a lot of free time or just want to relax after a long day. You can download mods and maps and drive pretty much wherever and however you'd like. The company which developed the game also seems very passionate about it and that's pretty cool. My friends all make fun of me but it's really not that bad. I'm on my second save because I've done everything in my first one (bought all the garages in the game and expanded them, hired all the drivers, drove through almost 100% of the territory). 

I recommend it if you like simulators (even though I don't find it that realistic) and if you like driving games. If you don't match if these two things at the same time, it might not be for you. :)
Endless time killer, active friendly community, continually updated & in general an amazing dev team!

Ah, Euro Truck Simulator 2. A great trucking game of the last decade tons of trucks to choose and customize from trailers to customize and choose and load with cargo. Yep Euro Truck Simulator 2 has it all while most of the base map is mostly out of date and some bits of it being updated on new updates. There're DLCs that let you explore more area's and countries and let you play with map mods that make the experience more enjoyable. Euro Truck Simulator 2 is certainly showing its age however, that hasn‚Äôt stopped it from receiving regular updates from a very passionate development team, on top of additional support from the trucking community. This game can be enjoyed by both casual players and car enthusiasts with options to adjust their trucks to the simulation they desire, whether it's performance or cosmetic changes.

Game Objective:

You start off by completing quick jobs with an employer's chosen truck. The further you travel and the more precious the cargo is, the more you‚Äôll get paid. Once you‚Äôve gained enough revenue, you eventually become your own boss of a holding company with the objective of delivering goods throughout Europe, allowing yourself to gain revenue to grow your business, upgrade your truck, and unlock different types of cargo missions by levelling up. By exploring the world, you will also unlock new areas to expand your business, new cities to start your journey in, find new employees to hire, new truck dealers to purchase from, and more.

The World:

It's massive and will only get bigger and better with the additional purchasable DLC map expansions. The base game includes access to Austria, Belgium, Czech Republic, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Poland, Slovakia, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom. The DLC map expansions expand on existing countries as well as adding new ones. The developers also tend to revisit the base game and existing DLCs expanding on them free of charge. While some parts of the world look great, it can feel repetitive, bland, and similar at times. However, the weather, the road accidents (both customizable) and the in-game radio tend to keep me distracted.

The Driving:

While I‚Äôm not a car enthusiast, this game provides you with a decent number of options for your simulation needs. The majority of these options will, of course, be more effective for those who have a gaming wheel. This ranges from driver fatigue, traffic offence penalties, transmission types, breaking intensity, suspension stiffness, truck stability options, force feedback, internal friction, and other simulation options to make it more realistic or to ease your driving experience. The more basic features are also included, such as adjusting your seat, mirrors, lights, and truck to your liking.

The Community:

As per usual, the community goes above and beyond for the games they love, and this game is no exception. TruckersMP, as an example (a free unofficial multiplayer mod), expands on what SCS Software has created and makes it better by improving and expanding outside of Europe and even out of trucks. Believe me, there are plenty of mods out there to improve your trucking experience!

Advantages of ETS2:

‚Ä¢ Regular updates.
‚Ä¢ Massive world (even without expansions).
‚Ä¢ Tons of customizable options.
‚Ä¢ Lots of different cargo.
‚Ä¢ The developers revisit the base game and the paid content.
‚Ä¢ Great modding community & modding support from developers.

Disadvantages and much needed improvements of ETS2:

‚Ä¢ Outdated textures (some have been improved on, but don‚Äôt expect AAA graphics).
‚Ä¢ Can feel repetitive with similar environments, bland/flat areas and long roads.
‚Ä¢ Needs more local roads!
‚Ä¢ Bad damage model. No noticeable truck damage and unrealistic collision.
‚Ä¢ Very basic business features.
‚Ä¢ Not really punished for breaking driving rules.
‚Ä¢ No option to customise business building.
‚Ä¢ The United Kingdom is very outdated and needs a ton of improvements (unrecognisable in some areas).
‚Ä¢ More cosmetics and intractable items.

So‚Ä¶ Should I buy it?

The concept as a whole is great and I‚Äôve had a ton of fun playing this game. It can be very relaxing and quite a fun experience especially when playing with others. However, the more I play it the more its age shows itself. This game could be so much better but for that to happen I feel like Euro Truck Simulator 3 would only rectify my issues with the game. I do recommend this game but only when its on sale as its stupidly cheap when on sale. I was originally gifted this by a friend and became quite addicted to it. I even ended up buying a ton of DLCs because of how amazing the concept and the community is! It can however get boring after a while but I find myself coming back every now and again to experience another trucking day :)
I cant help but keep coming back to this wonderful game, so good to relax and play at your own pace

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is not a dull simulator that will make you drive around. You can build up your company, take up whatever assignment you want. You can choose or avoid stressy jobs, and basically enjoy a lot of freedom while still having goals - but you're free to set them for yourself. Whether that is to discover the whole map, or build a big women truck driver harem spread through Europe. 

After all this time, the game is still being updated. Once in a few months, I pick it up again for a bit and the small added features and upgrades feel like little surprises that bring a smile to my face. It has gotten more beautiful over time and only for the pleasure of playing a game that still receives so much love, I'd recommend it.

Well, where do I start?
Let me be honest and say that I am a die hard FPS fan with the odd occasional racing sim thrown in.
A friend of mine told me about this sim and to say I mocked him for engaging in a dull, slow moving, driving sim would be an understatement. (In my defence, before he played this, he was raving about some train sim, which he showed me one evening. It was the longest week of my life! Ok hour, but it felt like a week).

Anyway I bought a VR headset and thought, hell, why not try it as there wasn't much else for VR at the time.

I'm a convert!! The base game is a bit small, but still big. I know it sounds a bit odd until you start downloading DLC's too.
 I love this game, it's so relaxing but slightly taxing as well. You get to drive a 40 ton truck across Europe and if you get the extra countries, which you will want to, then it does become a massive area to play in. There are plenty of DLC's and a large modding community. I downloaded ProMods map upgrades which gives you more roads, more towns, more buildings etc and their trailer pack which gives you real company trailers like Tesco, Lidl, Eddie Stobart to name a few. I've also downloaded mods from this site like real fuel station names, improved rain, realistic street lighting.

Playing the game, for me, is with VR. I don't know why anyone would want to play it any other way. VR is so immersive and although it needs optimising as I get a little bit of rubber banding at times and if I look out of the cab there are no wheels and the graphics are not quite a s good. The overall experience is that you really do feel like you are sitting in the cab of a big articulated truck.

You can start as a hired driver trying different trucks and when you have enough money you can buy your own truck, trailers, garage, hire your own drivers if you want. For me the fun is the driving and manoeuvring the truck and trailer.

If you want American trucking then American Truck Sim is exactly the same with its own mods. I own both and I love them both.

[h1] My honest review on ETS 2 [/h1]

This game is a lot of fun. At first, the game does not seem like it would be that much of a joyride. Looking at it, I believed it would be very boring to just drive around Europe. Oh boy was I wrong. With all that the community has put in, the new DLC (that I need to buy), the customization, and the endless driving opportunities, the game presents itself as fun as many other games on the platform. The game provides an interesting insight into the world of truck driving. There are many different and fun trucks to choose from as well as cool locations/cities to drive through. I have to also thank the developers for the many different graphics options for low - high end PCs. 

Overall, the game is as much fun as other games I have played. I have just recently bought the game but I am ready to spend many more hours on this experience. If you are looking to purchase this game, try sure to purchase it while it is on sale. It has regularly gone on sale during every steam sale and sometimes during weekend sales (when I purchased it). The DLC are also relatively cheap compared to other DLCs of games on the platform. From what I have seen, they contain lots more content to the already expansive base game and are a grand addition to the game. I am very excited to plow many more hours down the drain in this game. :)

The game is a sibling of American Truck Simulator and provide a little bit different experience.

>Be me
>See steam has a sale, check to see if GPbikes and TT Isle of Man Ride on the edge 2 are on sale
>TFW GPbikes hasn't released on steam and TTIOM 2 has concerning bugs
>See Euro Truck Simulator 2 on sale
>Realize how cheap it is
>"I am a motorbike guy, why would I buy this???"
>Download demo
>WTF???
>Game good! 
>Buy base game with essentials dlc pack and map booster dlc pack
>Play game for 3 days, max out long distance skill early
>Take cross country delivery job
>See that I have over 90 in game hours to make this delivery
>Wow! that's a lot of time
>Famous_Last_Words.exe
>Adjust my route away from the highway to include a few cities so that I can get some discoveries done
>3 rest stops and thousands of km/miles later
>Realize I still have lots more distance to cover
>Realize the delivery is due in 12 HOURS
>Realize that if I rest again I will be late asf
>It_Was_At_This_Moment_He_Knew_He_F**ked_up.mp3
>MEGA PANIC MODE
>OPEN WORLD MAP, DROP SWEARS FASTER THAN A VULCAN CHAINGUN
>TAKE A DEEP BREATH *SHARP INHALE* *calmmm*
>After making some estimations, I realize that by the time my character is tired, I will have 4 hours left to make the delivery
>I decide to step on the gas pedal and speedrun the rest of the journey
>Pause game, turn on Eurobeat, resume game, I am SPEED
>Haul ass for more than 1 IRL hour straight
>Character starts yawning
>GOD_PLEASE_NO.mp3
>I am only 2 in game hours away (30 ish IRL minutes)
>Police Car pulls up behind me
>Starts spamming me with "Avoid Sleeping" offence tickets
>Cant outrun him because I only have 420 horsepower and am driving with a big ass trailer several tons heavy
>Cant slow down because I'll risk becoming late again
>Cant speed because he will slap me with even more tickets
>F**k_The_Police_Coming_Straight_From_The_Underground.mp3
>More than 10 fricking tickets later, he leaves(R.I.P Wallet)
>FINALLY
>Begin ass hauling optimization!
>Slam my foot on the gas, character blacks out mid corner
>WAKE UP YOU IDIOT!!!
>Character wakes up, and the truck drove off the highway, dodged a barrier, and ended up doing 90km/h in the woods
>Luck 100
>Demolish a small tree and then get back on the road, take major damage causing the engine to periodically malfunction
>Ok... I almost f**king died there, new strategy
>30 in game minutes until I reach my destination
>If I black out again, I will lose control and crash again...
>TACTICAL INSOMNIA
>Put truck in 6th gear
>Cruise at 30km/h
>Angle truck facing the apex during corners to stop it from drifting into the barrier when I doze off
>6th gear has very strong engine breaking which will slow the truck down quickly when i lose control
>Crawl all the way to my destination
>Made it JUST IN TIME
>And just to flex, I chose the most challenging parking option while blacking out
>MISSION ACCOMPLISHED TOO EZ DIDN'T EVEN BREAK A SWEAT

I was a bit critical of this at first, but I've grown to love this game. It has an RPG-style leveling system to it, but its simulator nature means that there's really no encouraged or otherwise 'correct' way to play the game. I've never been able to say that about an open-world RPG before, and Euro Truck Simulator 2 knocked it out of the park. Also, there are so many options to customize the trucks, trailers, and just the overall experience of the game, and you can unlock more stuff for the first two as you continue to play. It does a good job of meeting players where they are too. I've played a lot of games where driving semi trucks is a thing, and this is one of the best so far. I highly recommend this.

Depression gaming at its finest, and multiplayer is hilarious. Great for relaxing, recharging, and feeling like you're doing something. Never before have I had to weave a truck between a street sign, a cop car,.and a rolled over truck that was driven (poorly) by a friend. Level of control and realize is up to you.

Ok, so I've only played this game for 14 hours, but so far, what I have played, is great. The detail in the game is astounding, and the fact that you can listen to your own music, or even tune into some IRL radio stations is epic. Gameplay is very smooth, but then to be honest, I play using a cloud gaming service, so as long as I have a good internet connection, it usually is. Admittedly, the only issues I have are the lack of some serious Grim Reaper art work in the game, but that's probably just me, and the fact that Free Roam is still highly limited to certain roads/motorways/highways and towns/cities.

I am happy enough with this game to consider streaming it over on my Twitch channel, but I am waiting until I get a steering wheel for my PC first (which might be a little while yet, giving me plenty of time to add more hours into it).

To sum it up:
Graphics: 10
Audio: 10
Available Jobs: 10
Free Roam: 9 

Overall, 9/10 from me

Let me start out by saying that the free demo gives you full access to the base game. If you're curious at all, try it. If you end up enjoying it you can buy the game and continue that same profile with zero progress lost.

There's so much I could say about this game but I'll limit it to this: Turn your suspension sliders, in the gameplay options, all the way to the left for maximum wobble. Turn signals do have an effect on the AI. Every street light has a red light camera that will automatically fine you. Cops are assholes. Quick Jobs lets you try out every truck in the game - with only money loss being from fines you may get.

Just give it a try for a few hours. It does get a better once you have a few drivers under your wing, but overall if you feel it you feel it

All I can say about this wonderful game is that Its of course,wonderful XD I still cant forget the nolstalgic moment when I finally hit France for the first time since I have been stuck taking job in the UK in game on my 2nd playthrough.It was nightime when I reach France. The most nolstalgic part is how those lights on the building lit up. Despite seeing France many times in game. By the time I reach France It was the time SCS just reworked the city of Lille. The city is just so surprizing beauiful and the highway is so realistically done that It was just nolstalgic,despite happening only one year ago LMAO. Though there are other nolstalgic moments back then. My final thoughts is that this game is very simple for a simulation,with very little challenge.(Real challenge only happend when trying to park the truck to unload cargo or taking heavy or special transport jobs)Despite that,It is very godamm relaxing,even on 15 FPS(Yes no kidding,I always play on 15FPS yet It is still more relaxing than many games I've played) It is just the best for stressful and depressed people(Judging by quite a few comment,and It really does heal depression) This game overall might be simple,but It is so relaxing and fun that you can forget all the complaints you wanna report to SCS, just admit It :) Although you will get random crash and rewarded a 100% damage with a ticket that cost 100 000 Euros to the repair shop.

6 hours worth and this might be the game I spend playing over the end of year break. Not sure what it is, the chill scenery, the knowledge that if I tried to handle a 12 wheeler in real life that it would start and end badly, the curiosity of the question marks I deviate some trips to go see to find out if its a garage, dealership or hiring firm (or what ever its called). So far I have been playing with speed limiters and speeding penalties (etc) off and have just been treating the roads as if I built them myself and that everyone else on them are there to my reluctance. This game makes me consider buying some peripherals specifically for it, which would be at least five to ten times what I spent on the game (+ some DLC's to unlock additional geographic areas) - I bought this because I was reminded it existed by that horrible English Patriot The Spiffing Brit (I can only hope his patriotism is just a persona for the novelty), but I have seen Limmy (World Famous Glaswegian comedian) play some on his streams (either this or the USA one) and so it's been on the back of my mind out of curiosity for some time. I'm glad it was on special after the reminder.
I agree with other reviews that say this game comes with a type of catharsis and that its oddly satisfying and somewhat unexpectingly a good game... It really casts a shadow on other "Simulator" games (not naming names, but you know the ones that become memes because the games a gag).
Other then all this, my brother is looking at becoming a truck driver, so I hope to get him over to play and/or give me tips, despite getting some of my initial joy out of driving like a sporadic psychopath, I find myself being pulled towards the allure of staying in one lane, using my indicators (blinkers), reversing the trailer into place upon delivery for extra EXP, and finding a great deal of satisfaction in these seemingly mundane activities.
Maybe I will try the online play at some point, I found out a friend has the game too so that could be fun... will wait and see. Hope this review helps!

The game is great overall, but it has some problems.

1. Most important stuff -[b]trucks, trailers[/b]. Vehicles are detailed and good looking. Also there are many customization options for both trailers and trucks. I was not disappointed despite my very high expectations. 

2. [b]Map[/b] in base game is big enough if you want to play casuallly, once in a while to chill out driving your truck across the europe, but if you want to play more often - I'd reccomend buying one or two (or more?) DLCs with maps and one with some unusual cargo.

3. [b]Multiplayer[/b] is done right. Sessions up to 8 players supporting mods and map extensions inside base game - everything works smoothly and it can be considered.

4. [b]The AI[/b]... well the artificial intelligence might be artificial but I would not call it intelligence.

This game is the closest thing to a Euro Trip I can experience in a post-pandemic world. Thank you SCS  Software for making this one of a kind game that makes that both possible and affordable.

I have had this game in my library for years and only decided to try it now while looking for something that offers an open world driving experience and a laid back one at that. After a few sittings, I decided to pick up both the Map Booster and Cargo Pack DLC to expand the game further and open up more exploration and scenic opportunities.

After the tutorial and first few deliveries, the game opens up and adds upgrades, garages, and exploration and transforms into a vast sandbox loaded with opportunities. After buying your first truck and taking on longer missions, all the finer details of the game start to show up in nice and subtle ways. I really like the dynamic weather effects, turn signals, different driving rules and patterns for each country, AI seems to change depending on the location or road patterns... England has terrible drivers that always ram into my trailer in roundabouts or merge into me on the highway on-ramps. Conversely, Netherlands to Luxembourg was one of the smoothest trips ever and the AI is less aggressive. I also play the game with an Xbox 360 Wireless Controller, and when drifting off the side of the road, there is force feedback from the rumble strip at the side of the road, so cool!

One of the best and simplest features in the game is the Internet Radio. You refresh the list and pick from lots of real live internet radio stations and stream any genre of music at any time during your drive. It totally makes for a great driving experience and becomes driving therapy. I like streaming classical music upon arriving the destination and performing the skill parking. Really brings back vibes of landing in a new city on the airplane and the pilot has the classical music and announces the weather and time.

SCS made this game highly configurable and moddable, so almost any gripe can be addressed. I turn off the traffic violations so I don't have to worry about speeding and driving rules and bad AI crashing into me and getting penalized for it. I also turn off fatigue simulation so I don't have to deal with rest stops. Anything to make the drive more relaxing. The cruise control feature is a nice touch. Setting up head tracking with Open Track and your smartphone transforms the entire game into an ultra realistic driving sim with the FOV angle independent of your vehicle controls.

This is such a great game and completely immersive and engrossing. Sometimes while playing, I forget I am driving a big rig and dragging a 40-ft trailer behind me. I only have some minor requests for the devs: 1) offer an auto-drive / auto-pilot mode (similar to RDR2 cinematic cam), because sometimes I just want to camera out and stare at scenery without worrying about crashing, 2) adding a wheel orientation HUD indicator in top-down cam would greatly help the skill parking (right now I constantly switch between top-down and wheel cam in order to back up perfectly straight), 3) add more ambient lighting during night parking (right now, I unhitch the trailer in order to brighten the parking area), 4) allow a zoom out level on the top-down cam so that we can clearly see where the parking space is.

Awesome driving therapy simulator. Highly recommend.

This game came into my life at a very low point and really helped me go through it. I flip burgers at McDonald's for a living and became really depressed because of it. My wife left me because of the nauseating smell of french fries I constantly had (I don't shower). She left with the kids and married a KFC manager. On top of this, I was playing with my dog and accidently set him on fire which then led to my house burning down. Yeah my life sucks as you can see but this is when I miraculously met a beautiful woman. She was so kind to me made a small doghouse for me to live in. She gave me a crappy laptop that apparently used to belong to her son called Games. When browsing on the internet I found the song called "Two Trucks Having Sex" which used to be my favorite song when I was a kid and it also birthed my truck kink. I quickly tried to find a truck game where I could make all my fantasies come true without anyone thinking I'm weird while also being able to afford it and found this game on sale. I also use this game as a coping mechanism to my trauma about the sword war of 84, I roleplay as a UNSC armorer who delivers energy swords. It's definitely my best purchase.

This is one of those games that surprise you - I thought that I would never be interested in a game about truck driving - and here I am after several years and over 200 hours in-game (and almost the same in American Truck Simulator).

This is a great, relaxing game, and if you invest in a good steering wheel - it's even more revarding. Over the years SCS Software added a lot of new contenct (both a free updates and also as paid DLC's) and the game is still in development.

A wide range of countries, cities and trucks makes it a great game for truck fans and gamers searching for a relaxing title. I usualy listen to podcasts or audiobooks while driving and it works really well.

I have so much to say about this game.
I started out with a poor performing laptop and did not have any extra accessories like a steering wheel.
I enjoyed the game alot and quickly racked up hundreds of hours. This game is definitely not for everyone. It's very relaxing and can be enjoyed on low-end devices.
ETS2 is priced cheap and has a huge selection of DLC's for both map expansions, cargo & customizing.
There's also a huge modding community in ETS2. With easy access to the steam community workshop or for  example the forum:  forum.scssoft.com.
If you've got an interest in big machines or a passion for trucking, defietely pick up this game and some DLC's to go along with it!

All in all, this game played a part in my inspiration to becoming a truck driver in real life.

Having gained some moderate enjoyment out of playing ETS2, I couldn't wait to try it out with a VR setup. It seems like a slam-dunk win in this regard: a slow-paced driving game with real immersion, the ability to check mirrors by simply looking instead of having to steer with one hand and try to control the view with the other, that feeling of really sitting high up in the cabin with all those blindspots.

Unfortunately despite claiming to support VR, the game really doesn't. The interface is terrible. I struggled to even get it started (it certainly doesn't play nice with SteamVR). You have to remove the helmet to get through the menus then put it back on again when you're driving. That would be annoying but not a deal-breaker. However it's the poor quality of the graphics engine really get shown up. It's absolutely terrible. The resolution looks like something out of the 90's, I haven't seen anti-aliasing this bad since GTA IV came out on PC and the game just flickers horribly all the time; it's absolutely headache inducing. I spent several hours checking out forums and tweaking settings but nothing came even close to resolving these fundamental problems.

If you're buying this for the standard flatscreen experience then go for it (be aware that you'll then need to spend more for maps and content, which I think is reasonable) as it's a decent game. Note that you'll probably need a steering wheel if you want to use it as anything other than a simple simulator (i.e. automatic gears, etc).

If you're buying it for a VR experience though then stay away. It's the worst game I've played on the headset so far by a long, long margin.

Harm's principle states that every individual should only be limited in their ability to harm others, and this game is exactly that limiter that would change those lost sheep and guide them back down the path of Nirvana. To quote, "Over the body and mind, the individual is sovereign."

I used to play League of Legends for days on end and would not do anything else but waste my life away on that god forsaken game. I used to be miserable, hateful and toxic, lashing out on my friends and ruining the relationships I had build up  throughout my life. As all my friends walked away from my life one by one due to the way I was treating them, the only thing that stayed a constant was my life spiraling further out of control. In a desperate attempt to save me, my friend tried to introduce me to another game so that I could rehabilitate myself and change myself for the better. 

That game would be Euro Truck Simulator 2.

Initially, I resented my friend for introducing me to this game as I believe that no form of tranquility could ever be discovered from a game that literally does only one thing well; that is, driving trucks. To add on, all i did was drive my truck into other cars, and kept on racking up speeding tickets.

However, truth be told, I had already embarked on a spiritual journey to attain true happiness. 

One job led to another. And another. And another. Then it dawned upon me why I started to enjoy this game.

The sounds, the background, the cities, the roads, the traffic and more. Everything about this game was simply surreal and heartwarming. Brimming with life and joy, this entire game holistically brought out a side of me I never knew I had, or rather, locked away for so long. 

It brought out respect.

Respect towards my family and friends, and most importantly, to myself. No long would I be trapped in a self-deprecating loop of sorrow and misery, and no longer would I bear anger towards others. I had truly begun to live once more. 

To anyone reading this who hasn't gotten Euro Truck Simulator and feel like life is treating you wrongly, please play this game. It changed my life, and it can change yours too.

You drive from A to B, then B to C... Sounds boring as all buggery and why would you want to do this in a game without shooting or constructing a fortress???

With just enough rewards to keep you engaged (new trucks, trailers, parts, paint, artwork, new maps, constant updates and mods!). Whether you‚Äôre chasing down that urgent delivery time to maximise that profit, or just viewing famous landmarks and locations, for some great photo ops (graphics are pretty nice and the trucks and trailers look great!!)

Then the sound! You can literally feel the strain (with a 47t load) of the rig when it climbs a steep incline, as you shift down to maintain momentum! Gives me goosebumps every time.

I‚Äôm playing this with an ageing Logitech GT Wheel/Pedals/Shifter and I swear, it feels pretty close to the real thing at times. The recent force-feedback update has made it even more realistic! Great stuff! Great price, you don‚Äôt need to buy everything at once, just the base game is plenty enough to sink your seat into.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is a very fun trucking game with a very realistic experience. If you have a very weak computer you can still play this game with incredibly low graphics settings. You can set up steering wheels with it, or just use a keyboard. There are lots of different trailers you can use, and a very large map to explore. This game has a ton of truck options to purchase, which is a big game changer compared to the american version of this game, where truck options are very limited. This game can be very addicting and fun for anyone who enjoys cruising around in vehicles.

Pros of this game:

- Very large map
- Very realistic
- Full support for steering wheels and pedals
- Lots of customisation for your vehicles

Cons of this game:

- Can get repetitive and boring after a few weeks (I frequently have to take breaks then come back)
- The AI for traffic can be a little bit crazy at times. (They could drive differently in Europe but I know Canadian road laws)
- Too many DLCs to unlock simple things

In conclusion this is a very good game it just needs some minor touch ups. I recommend this to anyone who likes vehicles and simulation.

I think this game is the best driving game ever aside American Truck Simulator. You have endless truck parts, you can install mods (maps, sounds, trucks,truck parts etc) which makes the game super cool. 

You can drive on lots of kilometers of roads, getting from A to B for example from Portugal to Finland takes like 3-4 hours if you don't speed, so that's how we're talking about distances, but if you put mods like Promods, and Rusmap, you can go from Iceland to Moscow or Longyearbyen to Portugal etc, so you get it :) )

The view is breathtaking, even if the engine is old, it can run kindof fairly on a Ryzen 3 2200G with its integrated GPU. Please note that, if you have a 1440p monitor, you will have some lags even at medium, so I'd prefer playing on 1080p. Unfortunately because of the lack of ICs, i can't buy myself a dGPU because it would break the bank.

"I would say I was playing 25 hours a day at the peak," says self-confessed gaming addict Habibi, now 69. "I kind of half block it out because I hated school so much but the worst year I can remember was when I was playing Euro Truck Simulator 2. I was 39, and I was getting up at two in the morning and going downstairs on to my mum's laptop to play. I was up until eight, and then I'd get back into bed saying I was ill."

Habibi's story is not so different from my own; we were both miserable as "teens", and we both played truant in the fantasy world of Trucks in Europe. Habibi's attendance fell from 100% in his first year of secondary school to 45% in his last. Mine was less extreme ‚Äì I would miss, on average, a day a week. In both our cases, every day spent off school was a day spent playing video games.

But in the end who the f**k cares and we both d*ed of Ligma. Cuz the truckz were too intense for us.

Been eyeing the truck simulator games for a while, and when they went on sale I decided to jump in. I didn't know if I wanted to go with the American or Euro, but the European trucks and the larger size of the base game made me pick Euro, and I'm happy I did. Enjoyable, relaxing game. Not too challenging, just you and the road. The optional "where do you want it" mini game at the end of each mission makes for an enjoyable little challenge, but once you figure it out it's not too tough to pull off quickly every time.

This game is always there, you can either be bored, too tired to pay attention, or just want to vibe in your truck and make some money and this game is great. I usually put a chilling playlist on spotify and drive for hours at night. Highly recommended although gets boring if you get serious in it. Also great for watching podcasts or youtube on a second monitor as you drive which gives off a great vibe.

I like trucks to the point where, as a birthday present, I got to sit in one just driving around. So, giving Euro Truck Sim a go was a no-brainer and, yes, its not only everything I hoped for but it's so, so but more. Why?

In a nutshell, this plays wonderfully in VR (using a Quest 2) and the level of emersion is off the charts and the graphics come to life in a way I never would have expected. I really feel like I'm driving a truck (badly - already I've been done for speeding, I've bumped into a few things). The extent to which the VR experience pulls you into the world verges on the sublime. I am amazed by it.

If you like driving, if you like trucks, and you have VR capabilities I urge you to give this a go. You'll be spellbound. Seriously.

Now you'll have to excuse me, I have a delivery to make.

Chill time: listen to your favorite tunes while you either suffer the amount of times your truck crashed or how many times your truck got upside down. Either way it's pretty chill, but please, try not to sleep while driving, it would be rather, unpleasant.

Firstly I'd like to say i'm not one for simulators let alone a one about driving a truck for a living, However I was actually really suprised about this one, It has somewhat great graphics, plenty of landmarks, vehicles etc. It is actually somewhat realistic and by that I mean you will face traffic violations and have to pay a fine. One thing i will say is that it has some hardcore, die-hard fans, even with complete radio stations manned 24-7 so that you can both listen and interact. there is a sense of multiplayer via an external mod. which does allow you to see other folks. 

Its certainly a game you can waste some hours on just driving around doing pretty much nothing, or if you are wanting to build your trucking empire up then go ahead, id recommend it to anyone especially for the price.

If you want to know what it's like to drive a cab of engine tractor trailer and don't want to spend thousands on getting a CDL then look no further. This game offers a hyper realistic experience in truck driving, time management, and navigation. 

For the record, you don't just drive trucks, you are running a business and will eventually be able to hire other people to take cargo for you (you do have to by a truck for them as well). I do recommend to buy a flat bed and an enclosed trailer ASAP, these will open up higher paying jobs.

Overall a great game, just be prepared to shell out a few hours whenever you want to play this, most jobs take at least half an hour, and there are times where it will be very boring, but it is worth the time.

Virtual Reality Review

Playing this (and ATS) with a VR headset and steering wheel combo is a dream come true. I can't begin to explain the feeling of immersion, or how satisfying this has been. (I think I've put about 30 hours of VR time on the game so far.)

When I put the headset on, I'm in a fully-realized truck cab, parked at a rest stop. I turn the ignition, grip the steering wheel, and my brain believes I'm there. I have a real-life coffee mug on my desk, and a virtual one on my truck's dashboard; more than once I've unconsciously reached for the virtual mug while caught up in driving.

There is a real coziness when VR-driving in the rain. You feel like the cabin is your little sanctuary, keeping you warm and safe from the elements. I wish we were able to get up and move around the cab, because I would park and sit on the bed during a storm.

If there are things that break the immersion for me, they are tiny. Sign posts still are usually hard to read until you're up close to them. And sometimes the dashboard or outlines of your mirrors flicker or bend slightly for a moment (it's not horrendous, and I've gotten used to it enough that I don't notice anymore). Ultimately, the clarity of VR shows you the imperfections in the graphics of the surrounding world, where you might not have noticed it on a monitor. I don't mind this one bit, and I think this version of Europe is charming and beautiful in its own right.

Playing this with the VR + wheel combo has completely soothed my thoughts of quitting my real job to become a truck driver. This scratches that itch perfectly, and it's everything I want it to be.

But its being constantly improved and getting better with each update.

One of the most amazing ways to spend your hard earned money. 

Have you ever dreamed of driving a big truck, but all the training and licenses and drug tests prevented you from living out that dream? Well now with ETS2 that's no longer a problem. Tear white-hot ass across Europe leaving death and destruction in your wake. Exploit the labor of your employees and build a trucking empire the size of which the world has never seen. ETS2 teaches you basic economics, as well as how to drive a truck, for one reasonable price.

I have found myself, on many an occasion over the years, putting this game on as a "relaxer". ETS2 is the kind of game you boot up when you are not really looking for some stressful challenge and really want to just chill out.

Euro Truck Simulator 2 is the pinnacle of trucking simulation, whether or now you like trucks, you'd like traveling throughout Europe at the helm of your majestic road vehicle, if you want to relax, it's also the simulator made for you, with Euro Truck Simulator 2 you can explore, drive, purchase, upgrade and manage your trucking empire !

I highly recommend ETS2 after 2634 hours and I wish SCS Software good luck in their future endeavours, may your truck sim empire grow beyond your goals and dreams !

A trucking simulator game seemed more like a job or time-wasting endeavor than anything legitimately fun. I downloaded the Windows demo mostly as a joke, to see what sort of nonsense gets rated highly positive. If nothing else, I could spend an hour causing chaos across the EU and move on to the next game on Steam. I ended up driving from Prague to the northern part of the UK In a single sitting. I never made a delivery but loved the drive.

I saw this title as being Linux compatible so I figured I'd pick it up to ensure this account had access to the bulk of Steam's features that are locked behind a purchase wall. Despite this Linux laptop being a bit of an old dog with only 4 GB RAM and integrated Intel graphics, it ran smoothly. THe occasional graphical hiccup emerged as detail was raised above low, but it performed perfectly well at low settings. There's a load of radio stations to choose from and if you opt to go online, you can join a server and talk to other players via the CB radio feature. If you want to remain offline, the single player experience is perfectly fun. Adding mods and multiplayer extends the experience and replay value considerably.

The gameplay is multi-faceted, including a business management portion, the actual driving simulator portion where you do missions, and the potential for a more free roam or sandbox style of play. Controlling the vehicle with a full-featured wheel/peddle/shifter setup is ideal, but the game controls acceptably well with a gamepad, keyboard, or even mouse steering. 

This title offeers a stronger community base and game mechanics for roleplaying than many MMO titles do nowadays, despite being a trucker simulation. Sure -- you can't be a wizard here -- but you also can't be a trucker in Black Desert Online.

Top tier gameplay, top tier community, top tier mods, top tier UI, and top tier Linux compatibility.

This game saved my life.

I am 69.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories

One of the best games! Although it's not really simulation, as time passes faster inside the game, all situations are taken from reality. Maybe it's the game I played the most. By this time I have more than 600 hours of playing, but I've lost previous record due to some machine issues, so I had to build all those hours and map exploration again.
Because of this game I felt that stay at home during the pandemic was something I could take with ease. Seeing traffic, buildings, new landscapes and so on gave me some feeling that I wasn't stuck at home all the time.
So, if you are a Sim-gamer, it's a must to have it.
If you're not, it's a must to try. At least, after some hours of playing, you'll see that guiding those machines is not that easy and drivers deserve some respect for their work.

This is a simulator game that is so clean and runs so well but It won't be for everyone.. The slow gameplay with slow progression will bore a lot of fast-paced players. 
But that's the charm and what i love about the game, it's accurate and is an excellent simulator of a trucking job.
Traffic violations and real world scenarios all trying to sabotage your journey of that clean drive and big paycheck. 
Realistic turning is hilarious sometimes, the amount of times I've sped round a corner just to fall on my side and destroy my truck. XD
I love to sit back, put the radio on and just let time fly while i drive casually down the open road.
If you want to just chill... Get this game, put your favourite songs in the games radio folder and sit back and listen while you deliver goods around the country.

If you like driving sims and truck driving in particular, look no further than ETS2 and ATS. The AI can be frustrating at times but overall it's an absolute blast to get on and drive trucks around the EU and Western US. The maps and scenery are wonderfully done. Keep up the good work and keep the content coming SCS team.

Technicaly nearly identical to American Truck Simulator, but in a European setting. Covers most of Europe as of now. Not just for truck nerds. Can be modded extensively. Unless you are a trucker or otherwise obsessed with trucks then I cannot understand why anyone would enjoy this game. The graphics are horrific, feels like a cheap game from 20years ago. The jobs are dull and repetitive. Any enjoyment from gaining xp and levelling up etc is nothing compared to the enjoyment you can get from levelling up in other games. Maybe it's more fun if you pay a fortune for a full driver controller setup, but if you are going to do that then there is a world of racing games that blow this game out of the water.

One of the most boring games I have ever played. i just don't get why this is such a popular franchise in this day and age. I can only think that the people that play this game are not really "gamers" but trucking enthusiasts with no real clue of how good games can be these days. Fair enough if you like it you like it, but I just don't get why.

This game is perfect for when you want something continuous and simple with a lot of soothing spare-time included. Fetching a trailer in northern UK and transport it to southern Germany, realizing half-way that everyone except you drive on the right-hand side of the road (oops) and having to reverse around a tight corner in order for the AI cars not to hit you... It is actually kinda exciting!

The best part about the game is that there is no real rush in it; Get in, do what you declare to do, reap a small reward (although it gets more fun when you get a really tight reverse parking spot to manage).

The only particular downer would be that the Linux-binary of the game does not support VR, which I was really hoping that it would. Oh well, still a couple of hours left until I get close to the 60%-map counter. Better get truckin'!
Quite relaxing and yet challenging if you want. The choice is yours.

out of the plethora of vehicle based simulators out there with wildly varying levels of quality (usually leaning towards the lower end) ets2 is, by far, the BEST one. 
it does what it sets out to do wonderfully and has a very supportive and active dev team constantly working on new updates and features for it and its sister game american truck simulator (which is equally as good). As well as this there are countless community made mods to enhance your experience, and the new convoy multiplayer is a great feature - driving with friends is a lot of fun.

if you are interested in driving games then i highly recommend checking this out - especially if you're looking for a more laid back experience

This game saved my life.

I am 41.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Sounds like the most boring premise in the world, right? I mean, who wants to spend hour after hour trundling along at the 55-60mph mark watching the motorway service stations go by?  Then I played it, and discovered that it's the digital version of crack cocaine. Like most junkies, I can't even tell you *why* it's so good.  Perhaps it's the cathartic effect of a growling engine and a swaying cab. Perhaps it's the attention to roadside detail that quickly becomes apparent in a way that no screenshots can ever do justice to.  Perhaps it's the satisfaction of slowly building up your own trucking empire.

All I know for certain, is that *this* is the game I originally bought a PC specifically to play.

Verdict - "Who knew trucks were so fun"/10

At first glance, Euro Truck Simulator 2 seems to fall right into this category of miserable simulator games. It is a game where you drive a truck around the European continent - from city to city, on a huge network of highways and country roads. Along the way, try to keep to the traffic rules, avoid crashing into other cars, refuelling and paying tolls on a regular basis, and if the trip is extra-long, take a short break in a parking lot somewhere to sleep.
It probably does not sound very fun. And considering the kind of rubbish we find in this genre, it's no wonder you judge it down and home at first glance. But as I have said before: What games are about is really irrelevant, it is what the developers make it that counts. It's fine to make good entertainment based on basically boring themes. And Euro Truck Simulator 2 is, in fact, a pretty good game.
Euro Truck Simulator 2 is ultimately about making money. When you start the game, you are a truck driver without either a car or money, but by taking jobs for various transport companies, you gradually build up your bank account. When you have earned enough, you can drop by one of the many car dealers in the game, and buy your own donation, which you can then use to make more money. Then you can hire new drivers and buy new cars, and build your own little transport empire.
The game has both licensed trucks, from manufacturers such as Scania and Renault, and fairly obvious counterfeits of cars the developers have not been given the rights to use - for example DAF, which has now given its consent to inclusion in the game , and will come in a free update . The cars you have bought can be further improved, and there are a number of types of accessories that you can buy. A lot of it is purely visual, but you can also upgrade the engine and so on.
