From my very first experience of this title over at a friend's house, to all those long hours behind the wheel, ETS2 has lost none of its charm. When I initially heard about it, and listened to what people who truly adored it had to say about it, I really didn't know how it could be possible that something seemingly so mundane could have the appeal they claimed it did. It didn't take me long to realise how right they were.

Obviously, sims like this aren't everyone's cup of tea, but for the people who are drawn to these types of titles (you know who you are!) ETS2 is - in my opinion - one of the best. Its current review status of 'overwhelmingly positive' speaks for itself, and the number of VTCs (virtual trucking companies) that exist via the TruckersMP mod adds another dimension and potential for interaction. The sheer scope for customisation in terms of the trucks in the game is vast, and the available DLC opens up even more for you to play with. 

And let's not forget how damn relaxing it is to just jump into the cab and wind your way through a simulated Europe, shipping things where they need to go. It might not be a hack 'n' slash, an FPS or an action RPG, but the kind of fun to be had from games like these does seem to scratch a certain itch.

I was very disappointed that i couldn't kill any prostitutes. Although, I was very hooked on the idea of getting the best truck and becoming the best truck driver to ever touch England. I started in Manchester and made way down to London. This drive was fantastic. I was able to see all the sites like the M1. Anyways after London I had a good amount of wonga to spend. So, I bought myself an Iveco Truck. This baby was called Flenck and could go from 0-60 in 8;14;48. She was could get me to anywhere in the world. Paris to be exact. This was the job of a lifetime. I was finally gonna get my big break ¬£28,942. Couldn't believe it. This was gonna set me and Flenck up for life, but then I sold Flenck for another a beautiful Mercedes. She was Slim but curvy in all the right places. Her exhaust was so silent and barely made a whisper even when I plowed that baby from Plymouth to London at a coooooool 58 mph. took me the good half of 10 minutes. was a delivery of tyres worth a whopping ¬£70, when I got to London (the second time) Me and missy (the merc) saw another truck, an Iveco. It was Flenck. She was being driven by another person. I was amazed and disappointed I didn't know what to think, but in a moment of genius I realised what had to be done. I had to kill Derek Ingleburt my arch nemesis driver, he undercut all my prices and he was driving a VolksWagon next to Flenck. I knew then that he had to die. This was outrages. He would go to London from Rome to Hamburg for ¬£4.20 where as any self respecting driver would do it for ¬£50,000. I'm suprised he's still in business and that he can eat. So I followed him to Flabba and beat him to death with a spiky hamster that was on fire. (quick detour: hamsters are from Israel originally). After that i had to hide the body. I did this by parking Missy in a Toys'R'us and parking her in top of Derek Ingleburt with a gun on Derek making it look lie a murder/suicide. Anyways, enough about me. Loved the game. Euro Truck Simulator 2 is an open world truck simulator game developed and published by SCS Software for Microsoft Windows, Linux, and macOS and was initially released as open development on 19 October 2012.[1] The game is a direct sequel to the 2008 game Euro Truck Simulator and it is the second video game in the Truck Simulator series. The basic premise of the game is that the player can drive one of a choice of articulated trucks across a condensed depiction of Europe, picking up cargo from various locations and delivering it. As the game progresses, it is possible for the player to buy more vehicles and depots, as well as hire other drivers to work for them. The game has never-ending play style.Gameplay follows an open world style, with players being essentially free to travel anywhere in their lorries, provided they can keep up with fuel, maintenance and toll costs, alongside fines if they incur any. When starting out, players choose their HQ's location in any of the game map's cities. At first, the player can only take what is known as quick jobs‚Äîthese jobs involve making hired driver deliveries while employed by a delivery company, with a provided truck and all expenses (fuel, road tolls, ferry crossings) covered. As the player earns money or takes bank loans, they can eventually afford to buy themselves a truck, acquire a home garage, and start accepting better-paying jobs by using their own truck instead of being a driver for hire with gear being supplied. Money earned in the game can be spent on upgrading or purchasing new trucks, hiring NPC drivers to take on deliveries, buying more garages and expanding the home garage to accommodate more trucks and drivers. The skills of the drivers hired by the player also grow with experience and the player can create a huge fleet of the trucks and drivers expanding the business across Europe.

As players progress and earn money, they are also able to purchase their own trailers, which can be fully customized in the same way as trucks. Player-owned trailers can be used to receive and deliver cargo at existing storage locations. Like trucks, trailers can also be allocated to company employees, resulting in higher income.

The player gains experience points after each delivery. A skill point is awarded after each level-up. Skill points can be used to unlock deliveries that require different ADR classes, longer distance deliveries, special cargo loads, fragile cargo loads, deliveries that are urgent and eco-driving. This progression allows the player to take on better-paying jobs.

The base game features 71 cities in twelve countries, over twenty types of cargo and over fifteen fictional European companies. There are seven map DLCs that expand the game to more countries and locations, and multiple other truck and trailer DLCs.

Maybe one of the best Trucking game I've played since now.
I always enjoy the rides from A to B, and gotta admit is satisfying seeing that Excellent after every safe and in-time jobs :D

Now about the game itself.
Looking at the first ETS and this one, you can already see they done a Good work. Devs are still bringing cool updates, at least lately they done a really nice job on the Sounds, Lighting, also finally including multiplayer to it is a really nice improvement.
The graphics are pretty good for what it ask for, but i would recommend a medium to high setup to enjoy it at a higher level of detail.
The physics are pretty good too, the wheels grip good on the road, so you should be careful how fast you take the corners, don't end up on the side of the truck :D
It has support for steering wheels and controllers, I don't have a certain list of the supported ones but I guess you could find one on the Internet, or you could just opt in for Mouse Steering in case you don't have a controller or a steering wheel, which I do love because I've rarely seen a game that has such a good Mouse Steering.
About it's content, they got Licensed Trucks, Scania, MAN, DAF, Iveco, Volvo, Renault, not all the models, but we got a few Old gens and also from the New Generations, which you can pretty much customize as you like, chose what ever color you want, there are some paintjobs also, change the cabin, chassis, engine, transmission, gearbox, slam some new rims along with some better tires, put on some lights, do what ever your heart wants. Don't forget, this game also has Workshop compatibility so, content, you have plenty of it.

And that's pretty much all i had to say about it, the price is all worth it, but I would recommend a sale for it, specially for DLCs since for me at least are a bit expensive some of them.

Found this game on sale, saw the reviews, couldn't ignore it. And after playing for 6 hours so far, absolutely phenomenal. I wish I had a wheel, but hey it looks like they have a Thrustmaster T248 giveaway coming up late September, so hey! Perfect time to hop on board! But without it on keyboard from my experience, I've been thoroughly enjoying it. The economy is very well tuned. I like the tickets mechanic, cause if you're not speeding much they usually don't bother you from my experience (except cameras). You can take loans to get your company started, earn money through hiring drivers and their own truck to use, take freight shipments with your own truck for more money. I would say early on to stick to doing quick jobs because if you damage the truck, your employer will pay for damages and etc. (56k one time... oopsies, I'm an Asparagus ;> )  But yeah, gonna be playing this for a while. Remember to train yourself early on to back in because experience matters a lot. You never know when you might need to back out of somewhere!

my first driving experience

i start in london
i get on the road
i immediately think "wait why is everyone on the wrong side of the road"
turns out it was i
so i broke several more laws and got onto the correct side of the road
got stuck because i can't drive in video games
i get towed
i leave where i was dropped off, real close to where i needed to be
i GO BACK ONTO THE WRONG SIDE OF THE ROAD [i]AGAIN[/i]
i proceed to drive on the sidewalk
got stuck again
drove myself out of where i got stuck
drove onto the wrong side of the road yet again
get back into my lane
pull into client's parking lot
decided at this point, backing up into the spot would be a terrible idea
picked the easy parking spot
drove there, no biggie
i did it

The best way to chill and relax while exploring new places and different world.
The new contents seem always exciting and SCS has been really dedicated for developing and improving the game through the years for nearly a decade now.
It is obvious a hard work is being done and there is very close attention paid to fine details.
In my opinion the main things this game needs to improve is anew user interface for the game, graphics improvement for the environment generally,  the sound configuration is done pretty well and I think it has been optimised to some extent even for 5.1 channel system so well.
Definitely would love to see more challenges, career mode with progress percent would be nice to have sense of achievement, but anyways overall the game is more than fun and enjoy to play.
Kudos for the Developers.
One of the Best trucking sims by far along with American Truck Simulator

Nothing is more important that trucking, this game has changed my life for the better. I no longer have interest in anything else apart from trucking. Hopefully one day this game will inspire future generations to truck. Delivering the cottage cheese and fish fingers to Aberdeen changed my views on society and I now understand the meaning of life. I have quit my job and left my wife and 3 children to lock myself away in my room from society just to truck. I have not left my chair in 75 hours and do not plan on doing so anytime soon.

Best game I have ever laid my hands on. Absolutely the most immersive truck simulation game of all time. Enjoyed every moment I have spent playing this game so far and have recommended it to all my friends and family. If you are somebody who loves to escape reality with the help of the European countrysides and cities than this IS the game for you. The sublime graphics make each second bewildering and amazing. Been playing the game for a good while now and honestly, it's been a hell of a lot of fun cruising across Europe and seeing all the different towns and cities.
Game still has its quirks every now and then, but what game doesn't? Especially when it's still expanding deeper into the heart of Russia - a place i'd love to explore in the real world at some point.
The United Kingdom and the older DLC may need some reworks as everything felt like it was copy and pasted; especially the depots. But, I won't fault them as the game is fairly old and they were working with a small team when it started. Some tunnels also need to be properly finished if they have been in the real world.
Absolutely love the game and can't wait to see it finished and I hope they keep tweaking and refining it as time goes on. Hell, it'd be awesome to see them add in electric trucks when they start coming out.

A hyper-realistic game about truck driving has absolutely no right to be this fun.

Beautiful graphics, wide array of jobs, great progression system.
Controls can take a while to get used to; E.G changing gears, using headlights, indicators, brakes, mirrors, micro-managing the GPS system, etc. But after a while it becomes easier and it's a whole boatload of fun.

You can also change the controls, use different control methods or just use a controller which is a huge plus- although I personally prefer just using KB&M. 

For ~¬£4 in the sale, I would 100% recommend. I don't think I would pay ¬£15 for this game personally, but I can certainly recommend it for that price too.

I can really see myself sinking a lot of hours into this game in the future. 100% would recommend.

It's a fun, realistic game. I like the fact that you get to manage the finances of your company. You get charged for speeding, crashing, blowing a red light, absolutely everything. It's super fun. Plus, you get tired, run out of fuel, get damage on your truck, trailer, and cargo which affects your final performance and rewards after delivery, not to mention your wallet if you need to repair. Unfortunately, it doesn't seem to be well optimized for macOS, it's just unplayable (my hardware destroys the recommended settings). But, it runs flawlessly on Windows (I'm using Boot Camp).

Personally I never play these kinds of games. However a while ago I bought this on sale for roughly ¬£4. I don't know why but this game was screaming for me to purchase it. So I did. Then I pretty much forgot about it for a couple of months. However the other day I decided to play it, AND WOW AM I IMPRESSED! To my surprise I really enjoy playing this game, it's so relaxing and I can easily spend a good few hours a time playing it. 

You start off as a truck driver for different companies. You get many different routes and destinations to choose from. (You have a wonderful little mini map called Route Advisor to guide you to your destination)
You also get to see the start and end destination before you accept the job. As well as the amount of money you will get for completing the job.

I'm fairly new at this game. So I apologise if I may be slightly incorrect. 

The further you get into the game, the more money and destinations become available. You can start saving up to buy your own truck and trailer to deliver goods. (Which I think allows you to make more money) You can also get more XP for parking the truck manually at set destination. 

The ranges of jobs are amazing. You can deliver many different kinds of cargo and drive many different kinds of trucks. What I also like is that in the UK, our drivers side is the right. And outside of the UK it is the left. The game takes this into account and it's a wonderful challenge to learn to drive both sides.

Another thing to take into account is Speed limits. Most roads/ areas you drive in have different speed limits such as 50mph/60pmh/30mph etc. You can also damage the truck. (I think you can turn this particular setting off) You can get fined for not using your headlights. It can rain. Be sunny and have thunderstorms! (You can turn your wind screen wipers on too!) All buttons are customizable so you can set out the best way for you to play. OH! did I mention there's a chance for some roadside incidents?

There is MUCH MORE to cover. 

Overall this game is great. I love it. You'll love it too.

This game, considering its' age, is one of the best simulators still around. This game really shows that there are developers around, that really care about their community. Either with TruckersMP or the home made ETS2 Convoy Mode, this game is fun to enjoy with friends and can deliver hours of gameplay. Europe and ofcourse the states around it are shown in incredible amount of detail, you can really see the whole game has been put together with love. 

Although some parts of ETS2 are still from the early times of 2012, like Great Britain, Poland or the Swiss/Austrian alps this game gives a great experience. Topping things off, SCS plans on reworking the alps region to fit with the rest of today's game. I really hope to see much more rework going on especially in Great Britain and I'm looking forward for the amazing "Heart of Russia" DLC! Thank you for the hours of joy and fun, this simulator makes me feel I drive a truck irl.
